urn:contentItem:5NWC-4B21-JB20-G31K-00000-00Government Web Sites Hacked; Trump versus Tinseltown; Trump versus Clinton; Explosion Burns Two Marines; Car Crashes into Pool; Shkreli Heads to Court; 20th Anniversary of Harry Potter; Bezos' Eyes on the Sky2017-06-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Kevin Kelly, Lee Carter, Gina Loudon, Pete PachalNEWSDomestic062602cb.231Government Web Sites Hacked; Trump versus Tinseltown; Trump versus Clinton; Explosion Burns Two Marines; Car Crashes into Pool; Shkreli Heads to Court; 20th Anniversary of Harry Potter; Bezos' Eyes on the SkyDagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Andrew Napolitano, Jared Max

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo.

It is Monday, June 26th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern time.

ISIS targeting our government -- Ohio Governor John Kasich's Web site hacked with messages threatening the president and his wasn't the only site affected.

Former Attorney General Loretta Lynch in focus -- the Senate Judiciary Committee now looking at her alleged interference. Former House Oversight Committee chairman, Jason Chaffetz weighing in on this probe saying both sides of the aisle should get on board.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JASON CHAFFETZ (R), UTAH: To have Senator Grassley in the Senate Judiciary Committee also going after this, it really is a pivotal moment. And if the Democrats are going to be fair and balanced about this they should be equally concerned about what Loretta Lynch did or didn't in her role as attorney general.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: A closer look at whether Lynch interfered with the Clinton e- mail investigation later this hour.

A scary scene at a California motel -- a car crashing through a brick wall and into a pool filled with children and at least eight people injured.

Martin Shkreli heads to court -- jury selection for his fraud trial gets underway today but he's already ignoring his lawyer's advice. We have the details ahead.

Plus Jeff Bezos has his eyes on the sky -- Amazon has a new patent for its delivery drones. The latest on his growing empire coming up.

Futures pointing to gains at the open -- you can take a look. Gains across the board, 64-point gain on the Dow futures right here right now. The Nasdaq composite on track for its eighth month gain -- eight months in a row. If you can believe it.

In Europe, we have buying across the board as well -- in England, France and Germany.

And in Asia overnight, same story -- green across that screen.

And celebrating 20 years of Harry Potter -- the book hitting shelves 20 years ago today and Facebook is getting in on the festivities.

All that and so much more coming up this morning. Maslansky and Partners' president Lee Carter, market strategist Kevin Kelly and CFRA investment strategist Lindsey Bell. Lindsey -- what do you make of these markets? Impressive.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: It's very impressive. Also a little bit worrisome given the run that we have had. We're up almost 9 percent year to date. That's usually what you get in one year on a good year. So I'm a little bit worried about what's going on in Washington and how that could impact the markets because usually in the second half of the year, starting August you start -- there's a seasonal trade down.

MCDOWELL: Nasdaq eight -- on track for its eighth straight monthly gain -- the longest winning streak in as long as you've alive. 22 years

KEVIN KELLY, CIO, RECON CAPITAL: Love it, baby. Well yes, that's an interesting point. I mean --

MCDOWELL: You missed that.

KELLY: I know -- I am 22. I love celebrating my second annual 21st birth day just a while ago. The best part is that technology has almost -- it performed double that what the overall market has. And so that's the interesting aspect because it's leading it so technology is correlated to the overall market 93 percent. So where technology goes, the market is going to go. So it's largest sector of the S&P 500 but I think the interesting --

MCDOWELL: The longer the banks leading the way -- right.

KELLY: -- right. The interesting aspect, though, that we are not talking about is the ten-year treasury is now at about 2.15 percent.

BELL: Yes.

KELLY: And so that's a crazy signal. So that's something to watch. I would have never predicted that when we started the year especially with the fed raising interest rates.

MCDOWELL: And just one thing about the tech stocks -- that market fell off and big tech names June 9th to the 12th that Facebook is now the first of those tech titans to recover from that selloff. The other ones Amazon, Netflix, Alphabet, Apple and Microsoft are still down from that selloff.

We have so much more to discuss this morning. Coming up, one of our favorite people on the planet Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano, the 2008 Clinton campaign chief strategist Mark Penn, and Fortnum and Mason CEO Ewan Venters is also here, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney joins as well.

You don't want to miss any of those fine gentlemen.

Returning to our top story this hour, Ohio Governor John Kasich's official Web site, one of several government Web sites lacked with pro-ISIS messages. The message reads, quote, "You will be held accountable, Trump; you and all your people for every drop of blood flow from Muslim countries." A hacker group called Team System DZ is taking responsibility for the messages.

Joining me now is conservative columnist Dr. Gina Loudon on what you make of this hack. Good morning -- Gina.

GINA LOUDEN, CONSERVATIVE COLUMNIST: Good morning -- Dagen. Good to with you. I think, you know -- go ahead.

MCDOWELL: No, no, no. I just -- you weigh in on what you make of this hack.

LOUDON: I was -- you know, my son reacted to this. He's only 10 years old. He said, "Wow, Mama, how in the world is President Trump going to clean up all the messes that President Obama left behind?" This is something that should have been addressed, these kinds of hacks going back over the last eight years.

But since Obama sat on his hand and did essentially nothing, instead of, you know, focusing on the things that this President is so good at focusing on like tax cuts and reductions in government and all the great things that Americans need him doing, he's having to backtrack to take care of things.

ISIS should not be hacking us. We should be hacking ISIS. That's where we should be with our cyber security. So I'm really glad that President did do the executive order -- I think it was just last week. And is addressing this and sharing this information between the states and the government agencies. It should be a great first step to fixing some of this.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: I think it's of particular interest to me that they've chosen John Kasich's site as one that they're going to be focused on especially with Kasich being such a vocal critic of Donald Trump and such a vocal critic of the health care bill, of everything that's happening right now. And they are putting that on his site among others. Why do you they that they are choosing him?

LOUDON: Yes. That's an interesting question. It honestly --- I think that it could be that they just really aren't aware of our inner workings of politics that maybe that you and I are aware of because we pay attention to it everyday.

But I also think that it could have been an attempt for more division among the leading party in the United States. I think that, you know, the more they can sow that sort of division amongst leadership that actually is in power right now, they might see that as some sort of advantage.

MCDOWELL: You know, actor John Depp, the latest celebrity to threaten the President. He was talking to a crowd in England at Glastonbury. Depp suggested assassinating President Trump. This comes after Robert De Niro said that he'd like to punch the President in the face, Madonna said she thought about blowing up White House, again the Kathy Griffin, the beheading that she somehow made herself the victim in all of that. The President's son -- the President's son Eric Trump responding to the threats from Tinseltown. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ERIC TRUMP, SON OF DONALD TRUMP: There are no quarters for this people. You see Johnny Depp and what he said, you know, I'd like to go assassinate, you know, the President. Johnny Depp has his own problems. He has his own problems. Like how about you go back to making movies and doing your own thing?

I mean this is a man who gave up his life to try and help this country. And he's doing a great, great job and I honestly I couldn't be more proud of him.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Gina -- do you believe that these celebrities are actually inciting violence. They clearly are doing it -- these are celebrities whose stars are fading or no longer exist and they are purely doing it for attention. But do you think that they are actually inciting violence as well?

LOUDON: Absolutely. And Dagen -- you make such an incredibly important point. The minute that somebody in Hollywood needs more attention or more money, they decide to say something like this and there really is no reprisal for this.

Whatever happened to Madonna? Absolutely nothing. But you know what it does? I mean could you feel more compassion for this son of the President? I was surprised he held himself together making that statement -- Eric Trump. And I tell you, the more I see of this first family, the more I feel just honored that they're sitting there in the White House, that they are willing to expose their family to this.

They didn't need this just like Eric Trump pointed out and yet they have really given up their time and their security, their own personal security and that of their own children and grandchildren just to serve our country. And I think that is one of the reasons that America wanted to see this president in place and I thought that Eric Trump's words couldn't have been nor poignant and more heartfelt.

MCDOWELL: You know, they run their mouths but all that money that they throw at these Democratic candidates -- look at Jon Ossoff -- that got him well, not elected. That got him nowhere.

Nine -- what was it nine to one California donations to -- in the state of Georgia -- donations in that election they lost to Karen Handel.

I do want to move onto health care. Because speaking of word -- former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton tweeted this on the GOP's bill. This was late Friday, quote, "Forget death panel. If Republicans pass this bill, they're the death party."

What do you make of that?

LOUDON: You just really want to put Hillary down for a long winter's nap or something. I don't know. She really needs to stop injecting herself because I really think that she looks like she's making a desperate gasp every single time she opens her mouth. And it's been that way since the whole campaign and that's how she lost. And that's why she was such a horrible candidate.

And that's why the Democrats are at all-time lows in their fundraising. And that's why Republicans are at all-time highs in there fundraising. And that's why the Democrats continue to lose that they are zero for four in these special elections -- or zero for five, however you like to look at it.

And as long as Hillary continues to be so dramatic -- sky is falling all of the time, right -- the more the Democrats are going to continue to lose because they have no leadership, they have no vision and they have no ideals other than to try to bring our president down. The American people don't want that.

CARTER: I mean this isn't just, I mean, ridiculous language. This is dangerous language. I mean to reshape the Republican Party as the death party in the wake of the shooting where we have Scalise still in the hospital.

LOUDON: Right.

CARTER: We're talking about saying, this isn't -- this is so far beyond just trying to reframe a party or trying to use language in a clever way to try and, you know, shift perceptions. This is actually going to the heart of the issue that we have right now which is that people -- you're not just against something. If you're on the other side, you're evil.

You're not just -- you know, not providing care, you are going kill people. This is unbelievably irresponsible from leadership. She's taking the anti- message that she had in the campaign to a whole new level here. And I think that at a certain point the American people have to say, enough is enough. We can disagree respectfully but to go this far, I think, it's too far.

LOUDON: Yes.

CARTER: And she's got to take accountability for this. What do you think is going to be the way that we can go forward without this kind of -- really inflammatory language where you're on such diametrically opposed sides?

LOUDON: You're so right about this. This is the dehumanization that the left is using. This is precisely what led to the shooting at the congressional baseball game. And they need to be held accountable for it. I believe the American people are watching this very closely. And I believe that until they sort of take responsibility for this death, violent environment that they've created, the American people will continue to hold them accountable because they see it clearly.

MCDOWELL: She's a former politician who is gasping for relevance but also inciting violence in the same stroke by using that kind of language.

But Gina -- you hear it from all of the Democratic leadership about how Republicans don't care about people's health, that they want to hurt people, they want people to -- you hear even language about people dying from cancer. And this is going to be more of the same if this -- if this healthcare bill comes -- if the Republicans in the Senate can pass it that they've got -- they've got to counter this message because it's not going to end.

LOUDON: That's right because what the Republicans -- the message that Republicans need to seek with the American people is that real compassion comes in giving people bootstraps, right, and telling people you can pull yourself out of where you are. And that you can save your money in health savings accounts, for example, and be responsible for your own health care.

The government doesn't need to be your daddy because that's what we spent the last eight years learning to reject. And that is what the American people went to the ballot box to reject over and over again. And I believe that ultimately the American people do -- we love personal responsibility, right. We love, you know, owning our own lives.

And that is what is quintessentially American and I think ultimately that's what we will come out with, with our health care. I think that we will never settle for socialized medicine that the left has tried to impose on. And I think that's why they're continually losing.

MCDOWELL: But we are in a situation now, Gina, where you are giving the government and bureaucrats and lawmakers more power over your health care. And until people wake up and realize that, that again, it could come too late.

Dr. Gina Loudon, it's good to see you.

LOUDON: Good to see you -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Take care -- Gina.

Coming up Martin Shkreli heads to trial for fraud. The charges against the former pharma executive once dubbed the most hated man in America.

And today marks 20 years since Harry Potter first cast his spell on children around the world and adults. How fans can join the anniversary celebration for the first book in the hit series?

MCDOWELL: Two U.S. Marines seriously burned in an explosion in San Diego. Cheryl Casone has the details. Good morning -- Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. Good morning -- Dagen.

Yes, that's right, these marines were injured while doing maintenance on a fighter jet at Marine Corps Air Station Miramar. This happened just last night. The base says that they were rushed to the UC San Diego Regional Burn Center. A spokesman says the service members belonged to a reserve squadron that is based out of Fort Worth, Texas actually.

Well, an SUV crashing into a motel swimming pool. This happened in Los Angeles. That pool was filled with kids. Police say eight people were injured when a driver of a vehicle lost control in front of the motel, crashed through a brick wall, landed right into the pool. This happened last night.

Sources are saying the children in the pool were not seriously hurt but were taken to a nearby hospital to be evaluated just to be safe. And cops say the driver appeared to be in his 20s. They're investigating whether he was under the influence of drugs or possibly alcohol.

Well, Martin Shkreli goes on trial today in a Brooklyn federal courtroom for allegedly defrauding investors. But the former pharmaceutical CEO doesn't seem to be worried about it. In fact he tells the Associated press he's excited and he can't wait. Prosecutors say Shkreli lost millions of dollars through bad trades and his side business that was a hedge fund, that he eluded (ph) a second pharmaceutical company for $11 million to pay that hedge fund -- those investors back.

His defense team says he never intended to scam anybody and that everybody was paid back. Prosecutors differ on that one.

Well, it has 20 years since J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter was first introduced to readers around the world. The eight Potter novels have sold more than 450 million copies over years.

And to mark the 20th anniversary, Kevin Kelly, Facebook has a new feature for you. I know you love this. When you type the name of any of the four Hogwarts houses into a poster comment it appears in that house's color and then an animated wand appears when you click on the names which cast a big spell.

I just kind of think you might be into it. I don't -- I'm guessing actually. You like a Potter --

KELLY: Yes. I actually used to go to the drive-in movie theaters back in Arizona. So they were great films.

MCDOWELL: Really? Yes.

KELLY: Yes. Of course.

MCDOWELL: No, I mean I'm not disputing that they're great films but --

KELLY: Yes, yes. The drive-in movie theater -- I know it was right there on the reservation. And it was perfect. It was packed. I can't tell you how many -- it was always, always packed for Harry Potter films. You had families, people bring out couches, watch it. It was a great time. Everyone was sharing popcorn.

MCDOWELL: Is it wrong that I rooted for Voldemort?

KELLY: No.

MCDOWELL: It just seemed right at the time.

Still ahead, Loretta Lynch in the hot seat -- the former Attorney General facing new questions over her role in the Hillary Clinton e-mail server scandal. What to expect from the Senate investigation?

And Amazon's vision for the future generating a lot of buzz. The wild new beehive for delivery drones that might be coming to a neighborhood near you.

MCDOWELL: Amazon moving forward with its drone delivery plans. New images from a patent application show how the company would tailor its fulfillment centers. They show a beehive shaped tower and the application for the patent says that this would help the company make deliveries in urban areas.

Joining us now is Mashable tech editor Pete Pachal. This may not be what the final version looks like but it does give you insight into Jeff Bezos' brain, I guess.

PETE PACHAL, TECH EDITOR, MASHABLE: Yes. He's definitely thinking long term on this. Yes. You can just imagine in the future every city has an Amazon drone beehive at the outskirts that, you know, that's just constantly buzzing.

But it's interesting. If you compare this idea with the very first unveiling of Prime Air which is what they're apparently going to call this drone service -- that was like a drone at the end of like a conveyor belt. And it was basically the drone tacked on to this already human warehouse.

So basically what this does is kind of flip the script on that. It's like ok, let's think drone first. You know -- and the humans are extra. You know, like the drone is the driving force within this warehouse. What would that look like? And they came up with this which is -- ok, it's looks a little like something from out of the matrix but, you know, I can definitely see the line of thinking there.

KELLY: But can rules and regulations get to there because the drone market is very heavily regulated and the FAA is going to have something to do with it? Is this even feasible or conceptual to put in reality?

PACHAL: I think it's feasible but absolutely, you're 100 percent correct that the regulatory and safety issues have yet to be fully resolved.

Amazon is obviously thinking a lot about that as are others like Google. And what ultimately needs to happen on these drones is there needs to be like multiple redundant systems so that if one fails, another one that's completely independent can take over. I mean really that's the only way you could safely have these aircraft in the air all over the place with a human below even if it is a sparsely populated region.

So they're thinking about this. So this is definitely longer term. I mean again, the first days of this is going to be drones tacked on to those Amazon warehouses and eventually it will get this maybe, I don't know, decades in the future.

MCDOWELL: The Bezos empire is growing rapidly, of course, especially in the wake of the Whole Foods acquisition. This is the kind of move that I was standing in a Starbucks and when it was first announced, I was flying back -- I think I was at the Milwaukee airport and the people at Starbucks are like hey, oh, my gosh, check your phone, Bezos is buying Whole Foods. So it was that kind of reaction.

PACHAL: Get your latte quick because, it could be Starbucks next. Yes, it was huge. I mean, you know, not many people and companies can really upend whole industries, you know, with a quick action like that. I think I read somewhere there was something like 50 million or -- sorry, 50 billion, 60 billion market cap difference when you take into account how much his competitors fell and how much Whole Foods went up.

KELLY: But Amazon is focused on groceries?

PACHAL: Yes, very much so. And this dovetailed nicely with the systems they were unveiling a few months ago, Amazon Go which is that grocery store of the future where there are no lines and there's intelligent systems throughout the store to know what you're taking off the shelf and know what's in your bag. And you basically just walk out because it just tallies up you're -- what you've taken and bills your Amazon prime account.

BELL: So what's next, the Bezos empire, like you said it's a huge one, they're in the grocery, they've got their hand in a little of everything -- where does he go next? What's the next -- what does he have his eye on?

PACHAL: Well, it's hard to predict.

MCDOWELL: You're kidding.

PACHAL: The thing is, he's learned some lessons about not getting into places he should not. Whenever people talking about Jeff Bezos and like how he's brilliant and how he can move whole industries -- I always say remember the fire phone where he came out and decided, ok, I'm going to do this phone because I need to compete with Amazon and Google.

He felt pressured and if you read the reports on how that was conceived, he very much was very hands on and micromanaged the design of that. It was a complete flop. It did not work.

So he is not infallible. And he can do things wrong. So I think he's learned from that. You can see his acquisitions and his actions since like the Whole Foods -- what makes a ton sense for his empire, but you know, you've got to have to caution that --

KELLY: But he pivoted and moved it fast -- the fire phone flopped but guess what he came out with? The echo and now everyone is following Amazon's lead in that regard.

PACHAL: Exactly. And he does have an ecosystem. And I love also how he's leveraging Amazon to sell the Echo. I mean there's all these other companies like Apple's Siri and Google Home -- they are coming out with these speakers. But -- we are all trained to go to Amazon.com to buy pretty much everything we want. And he has that portal to sort of put the echo and those products in front of everyone. Hey, you want this, you want this. You're buying some back scratchers. Hey, you want this Echo, too.

MCDOWELL: And I'm old enough to remember when he was working at a hedge fund here in New York City before he even founded Amazon.

PACHAL: I met him at a dinner like about 15 years ago when Amazon was just expanding into consumer electronics, selling on line. And kind of -- he's changed a lot, I would say, he was much more outgoing and gregarious at that dinner and I see him speak publicly now and he's obviously a changed man and he's really --

MCDOWELL: Not giving you any ideas.

PACHAL: Yes -- very guarded now. But I mean he's also -- I still see that sort of genius and that excitement in sort of his ventures. You looked at Blue Origin which could, in the long term be his most lucrative venture in shipping things to space. There's a lot (inaudible).

MCDOWELL: Pete Pachal -- good to see you. Thank you so much. We covered a lot of ground.

PACHAL: My pleasure.

MCDOWELL: Take care.

Coming up: the investigation into Loretta Lynch -- senators launch a probe into the former Attorney General's role in the Clinton e-mail scandal. Judge Andrew Napolitano will take a look at the legal implication.

And Facebook making friends in Hollywood -- look out Jeff Bezos. The social media giant is trying to take on Netflix and Amazon Prime with its own original content. The huge cost the company is reportedly willing to pay for new shows.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 26th. Your top stories at 7:30am Eastern Time.

It's Energy Week at the White House, President Trump set to host the Prime Minister of India in Washington this afternoon. And the week will highlight our country's energy dominance including a multibillion dollar natural gas deal with India.

Former Attorney General Loretta Lynch under fire, the Senate Judiciary Committee looking into her involvement in the probe surrounding Hillary Clinton's email while she served as Secretary of State. Former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales weighing on the probe with our own Maria Bartiromo on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALBERTO GONZALES, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL: I think that they're all legit in the questions raised by some of these allegations and I think that it's perfectly appropriate for the congress. The Judiciary Committee to examine exactly what happened here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The details on that investigation ahead. SpaceX pushing the final frontier, the company launching and landing not one but two rockets over the weekend, what the move means for the space race coming up.

And Facebook taking on Tinseltown, the details as the social network hits the walk of fame in search of scripted content, it's going to cost them.

Futures showing the market gains across the board in Europe as well. Stocks are heading higher as we wrap up the month of June. In Asia overnight, markets finishing the day with green across the screen.

Plus, chipping in for the win, the highlights as Golfer Jordan Spieth wins the Travelers Championship out of the bunker and into the hole, there you go.

We're moving on to this story because we want to get Judge Napolitano right now. The Senate Judiciary Committee looking for answers from Loretta Lynch on whether or not she intervened in the Clinton email server investigation. One of the question in the letter to Loretta Lynch reading, "During your time in the Justice Department, did you ever have communications with Former DNC chairwoman Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, her staff, her associates, or any other current or former DNC officials about the Clinton email investigation?"

Let's bring in Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Judge, can they force Loretta Lynch to testify?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Yes. Of course they can force Loretta Lynch to testify.

I agree essentially with what Former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales told Maria yesterday in the clip that you just ran but I would actually extend it one step farther, there is enough evidence here just on the basis of the little snippets given to the Senate Intelligence Committee by Former FBI Jim Comey that Mrs. Lynch was either conflicted or working at odds with the Justice Department and in behalf of Mrs. Clinton's campaign and the DNC when she told them to use different terminology for the investigation.

Now the terminology really doesn't matter, the FBI was investigating Mrs. Clinton anyway, but the terminology, let's call it a matter not an investigation. This result to some FBI agents teasing the director saying, "Oh, you're not the director of the Federal Bureau of Matters rather than Federal Bureau of Investigations." But the terminology maybe indicative of a mindset on the part of Attorney General Lynch that she was going to do whatever she could to prevent Mrs. Clinton from getting indicted and the Senate Judiciary Committee is entitled to inquire into that.

So is the Justice Department. This is not under Bob Mueller, this does not involve with the Russians. The DOJ itself, Jeff Sessions can assign a team of investigators, FBI agents, and prosecutors to investigate his predecessor as to whether or not she obstructed justice or behave in a way that constitutes misconduct in office by preventing or doing everything she could to slow down or impede the investigation of Mrs. Clinton.

KELLY: Judge, wasn't it not only just what happened with Comey's testimony but there's also assertions that she actually did tell other democratic operatives from -- that she would prevent this matter from going too far.

NAPOLITANO: That's the reason for the question that Senator Grassley's people wrote to Attorney General Lynch about her communications with Debbie Wasserman Schultz, a congresswoman from Florida and at the time the Chair of the Democratic National Committee.

It is alleged, this document has not seen the light of day if it exists that there is one or several emails between Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Loretta Lynch concerning the behavior that Loretta Lynch will take to further the DNC interest while Mrs. Lynch was the Attorney General. That if it happened would be misconduct in office.

MCDOWELL: What's the punishment then?

NAPOLITANO: Well it's a felony depending upon exactly what charge -- what they charged her with, it could be five or ten years. In jail it's very serious, it's the equivalent of obstruction of justice, same allegations they're making about the president.

MCDOWELL: Incredible. Let's move on to Supreme Court Justice, Anthony Kennedy is said to be -- there have been some reports out that he is considering retirement but Kennedy has given no indication if that is true or not.

The 80-year-old court veteran has long been viewed as the critical swing vote among his peers, often casting the breaking vote on contentious cases. White House Advisor, Kellyanne Conway refusing to divulge if Kennedy had reached out President Trump about his future, listen to this.

And somebody who has a judicial temperament and a record that's beyond repose as to Justice Gorsuch.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Justice Kennedy, this is intriguing, scheduled a weekend sort of get to together with all of his former clerks, one of whom is Justice Gorsuch for the fall of 2018, they moved that to this past weekend. Hint, maybe he won't be on the bench in the fall of 2018 on the other hand, he has four incoming clerks whom he's hired who are coming in in the fall of 2017. So we're getting mixed signals. He will either make an announcement from the bench this morning at 10:00am Eastern Time when the court convenes or he will decide, "You know what, Neil Gorsuch is my former clerk, he's a brilliant wonderful justice, I want to enjoy a year or two working with him on the court before I go." It got to be one or the other.

MCDOWELL: Could we also get some sign from the court this morning of what they might do, some kind of guidance on the president's executive order?

NAPOLITANO: I think we're going to get more than a sign we're going to get an announcement. They're either -- they are scheduled to release announcements on applications for this isn't a case before them because it's not over with it, it's an application for emergency relief.

They are scheduled to issue orders at 9:30 this morning about how they're disposing of them. If they simply say denied, that means that the stays, stopping the president's travel ban, stay in place until these cases are tried. If they do anything other than denied, they will have to have some specificity in there. The question is, should the travel ban stay in place while it is tried in a federal court in Hawaii and a federal in Minneapolis or should it not stay in place? Well, it's being tried.

KELLY: Well the answer is --

NAPOLITANO: It still hasn't been tried.

KELLY: The answer is yes, right? I mean --

NAPOLITANO: No. There's no way to know, it's going to come out in two hours. We'll find out then.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's very exciting.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. Yes. Yes, it is.

NAPOLITANO: We have producers in the courtroom, we'll know immediately. It's going to come out and we have red flags and white flags so we'll know because they take your Blackberries and your Iphones when you're in there.

urn:contentItem:5WK1-55T1-JBG3-64MM-00000-00Government Won't Protect Your Privacy2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisSection AColumn 0Editorial DeskPg. 21Government Won't Protect Your PrivacyBy KEVIN McCARTHY

Kevin McCarthy, a Republican of California, is the House minority leader.

Imagine that Congress proposed a law that made postage free in the United States. Even in the digital age, this would be quite convenient. The only catch? In exchange for free mail, postmasters would be permitted to open your mail and read our letters and bills. The benefit, postmasters would insist, is they would know when you're planning a family vacation. And then the post office could send you hotel recommendations or advice for the best restaurants and activities.

Convenient, right?

On second thought, you might rather pay the 55 cents for postage if it meant keeping advertisers from knowing the location and itinerary of your family vacation before you even get on the plane.

We prefer that strangers not read our mail -- that's why we've made doing so a federal crime punishable by up to five years in prison. We have blinds because we don't want outsiders peering into our homes. We have laws to protect our health care records because we definitely don't need strangers knowing our medical history.

So why should we treat our online identities -- and privacy -- any differently?

The answer to this question -- posed by my friend Tom Siebel, a tech entrepreneur -- clearly is that we should not. But if we are to secure our data in an increasingly digital world, should we expect government to singularly and effectively do the job for us? I would argue, no.

Some politicians, primarily those running for president, have called for brute government intervention, including breaking up big companies like Google or Facebook. This clarion call has the benefit of simplicity, but has failed to explain how it will increase security for our data. What does forcing Facebook to sell WhatsApp have to do with Facebook or WhatsApp collecting, exploiting and selling our data?

Others are calling for invasive congressional regulation. But as history tells us, overly broad and indiscriminate regulation often insulates the incumbents and boxes out the upstarts and smaller firms -- a consequence we've experienced with the Dodd-Frank financial regulations law. Even Facebook's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, acknowledged this possible outcome to Congress a year ago.

Unsurprisingly, these remedies lean on the premise that only government can solve market inefficiencies that lead to irresponsible corporate behavior.

I don't think we should feel confident that the bureaucratic leviathan has what it takes to develop or enforce nimble responses to rapid change in the technology industry.

We should look instead to the greatest driver of competition, the free market, for the most compelling responses to our privacy concerns.

Technological advancements can meet Americans' demands for privacy, and perhaps already are, through cryptonetworks. Cryptonetworks are decentralized platforms governed by the community of users rather than by chief executives or small management teams.

You would access these networks by logging on to a browser similar to what you use today. But the piping undergirding the decentralized networks is powered by blockchain technology capable of delivering stronger data security, portability and privacy for every user.

When you purchase or post something on a blockchain platform, the network will verify your identity using an encrypted key that is permanently and exclusively yours. Each action is recorded on a distributed ledger. This will make fraud nearly impossible.

Under the current internet framework, users' data is usually controlled by the platform -- online consumers leave a trail of data bread crumbs, making us vulnerable to privacy invasions. In a decentralized network, however, our data would be controlled by this blockchain encryption. Users would grant and revoke access to data, no longer entrusting third parties or tech companies with that responsibility.

Furthermore, this technology would increase competition, because blockchain makes it easier for anyone to create an alternative platform for communicating or providing some service. With the open-source nature of blockchain technology, a community of users is free to take what they like from an existing platform to a new one if they feel their privacy has been infringed or trust violated. Accountability is built into the system.

Each new platform is a fresh opportunity for users and creators to interact, shop and communicate without Big Brother or Big Tech tracking every move.

[If you're online -- and you are -- chances are someone is using your information. We'll tell you what you can do about it. Sign up for our limited-run newsletter.]

In many respects, it is a throwback to the permission-less innovation that brought us the internet we know today. For the free market, there is no better remedy to monopolistic behavior.

That is not to say that there is zero role for government. The Federal Trade Commission should step in when companies break the law or violate settlements with consumers or the government. Indeed, the F.T.C'.s role is perhaps more important and challenging than ever, because big tech continues to grow bigger.

Congress also has a role. It should develop a clear privacy framework that sets one federal standard for the country and adheres to three simple principles: You should be able to see, control and delete your data. These standards have the advantage of being bipartisan, which in today's Washington is saying something.

While the obscurity of blockchain might make it seem intimidating, we are seeing leading technology companies and venture capitalists looking to bring it into the mainstream.

As the most technologically advanced country in the world, it is America's responsibility to give this technology space to run and grow. Companies that have repeatedly broken promises to their users deserve scrutiny. But the federal government must not mistakenly turn scrutiny into suppression.

In the right ''light touch'' regulatory environment, decentralized networks can provide the transparent, secure platforms that respect an individual's privacy and dignity.

Kevin McCarthy, a Republican of California, is the House minority leader.

urn:contentItem:5TRG-HJV1-DXVP-V3NH-00000-00Governor Mike Parson Announces Eric Schmitt as the Next Attorney General of Missouri2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisNEWSGovernor Mike Parson Announces Eric Schmitt as the Next Attorney General of MissouriStaff Writer

Today, Governor Mike Parson announced Eric Schmitt as the next Attorney General of Missouri.

Governor Parson said, "As Governor, I take the responsibility to make appointments very seriously. Now that Josh Hawley will soon be serving in the United States Senate, I have the responsibility to ensure we provide stability and instill confidence for all Missourians that their government will continue to work for them."

"I am incredibly proud and pleased to announce that Eric Schmitt will be Missouri's next Attorney General. It was important to appoint someone who has already been thoroughly vetted by the people of Missouri. Eric is someone who I highly respect, personally trust, and have full confidence to serve as Missouri's chief law enforcement officer," said Governor Parson.

Incoming Attorney General Eric Schmitt said, "I want to thank Governor Parson for the opportunity to continue serving Missourians as their attorney general and chief law enforcement official. Governor Parson has been a truly outstanding governor for the state of Missouri who is moving our state forward on so many important areas for Missouri families.

"It is an incredible honor to be named the lawyer for 6 million Missourians, and I promise to fight each and every day so that the next generation of Missourians have the same opportunities I've enjoyed in the greatest country on earth. I believe everyone is granted the right to be treated equally under the law. No matter who you are, what race or religion you are, your background, your creed – every single person is entitled to equality of opportunity and a fair shake under the law," said Schmitt.

Attorney General Josh Hawley showed his support and said, "Over the past two years, the men and women of the Attorney General's Office have taken on some of the most powerful forces in Missouri and across the country to defend the people of this state. We filed one of the largest lawsuits in Missouri history to hold accountable opioid manufacturers, fought the federal government to undo burdensome regulations on Missouri farmers, executed the largest human trafficking raid in Missouri's history, and launched investigations of the country's most powerful big tech companies."

"The Attorney General's job is to fight for Missouri families regardless how big or powerful the opponent may be, and I know Eric Schmitt will continue this important work. He is a constitutional conservative and has a proven record of standing up for taxpayers in the Treasurer's office. I applaud his willingness and commitment to fight for Missourians as the next Attorney General," said Hawley.

Schmitt comes with great experience and qualification to this new role. Schmitt was sworn in as the 46th Treasure of the state of Missouri on January 9, 2017. During his time as State Treasurer, he has protected Missouri taxpayers, supported small businesses, and empowered individuals and families while overseeing the state's $28 billion budget.

Schmitt attended DeSmet Jesuit High School and continued his education to graduate cum laude from Truman State University, where he founded a Habitat for Humanity chapter. After graduation, he attended law school at Saint Louis University where he received his J.D. and served as an editor of the Law Review.

Schmitt's record of accomplishments serves as a reflection of his values and leadership. During his time as an Alderman for the city of Glendale and his two terms in the Missouri State Senate, he worked to cut taxes for working families, improve educational opportunities for Missouri children, and advocate for those with special needs.

He and his wife, Jaime, have three children, Stephen, Sophia, and Olivia.

Josh Hawley will resign from the Office of Attorney General effective January 3, 2019.

Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza Violence2009-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisGov. Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza ViolenceWalthamFULL TEXT

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," President-elect Obama's choice for Commerce Secretary, New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson, well, he's bowing out of the position. We're going to find out why and what it means for the Obama administration.

And President-elect Obama rolling out a new stimulus package; he plans to discuss it with lawmakers today. We're going to have all the details.

And the House Financial Services Committee begins an open session today exploring Bernie Madoff's alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme and how the SEC missed it. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And it may be too early for a hamburger, but we'll take a look at the rivalry between burger giants, Burger King and McDonald's.

Today is Monday, January 5th, 2009. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning. And welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." Happy New Year everyone, I'm Alexis Glick. Back in the seat and ready to go.

Well, we're going to get the latest on Governor Bill Richardson's stepping away from his job as Secretary of Commerce in just a moment.

And the Madoff hearings begin today. The House Financial Services Committee will probe how it is that the SEC missed the scheme. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And what will 2009 look like for trading? We get hopefully off to a good start; at least so far. We'll continue to see whether or not that will work through.

And why would anyone want to start a new football league in this economy? We're going to find out.

But first take a quick look at the U.S. futures this morning as right now we're down 16 points; 8,942. The S&P right now down 1.60. The NASDAQ down 2.75, but we had climbed above that 9,000 mark just late last week which we hadn't been to since early November, we'll see whether or not it shapes up to be a good year.

Well, let's get things started this morning with the three things you should know.

President-elect Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats meeting today are looking to put forth a plan for $300 billion in tax cuts to both individuals and businesses. This is an attempt to gain Republican support for his more than $700 billion economic stimulus package.

And French President, Nicolas Sarkozy lands in Israel today to meet with Israeli and Palestinian authority leaders. Now, the president is there in an attempt to push for a cease-fire in of course, the war-torn Gaza area.

On the ground this morning Israel struck at new Hamas targets in Gaza as it tries to rein in rocket attacks by the terrorist group.

And Microsoft's dominance on the Internet, well it may be waning. The software giant saw the share of its Internet browser Explorer drop from 74 down to 68 percent last month. Making the biggest inroads -- Mozilla Firefox which landed 21 percent of the market share.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now, for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, we go to Ashley Webster in London. Good morning Ashley and happy New Year.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS EDITOR: And happy New Year to you too Alexis, and welcome back. Good morning everybody.

We're off to a positive start and certainly in Asia overnight and so far in Europe we are also moving higher although not exactly setting the world on fire, but we are higher, and that's good.

London Exchange, the FTSE 100 up about a quarter of a percent, just a little more than eight percent. On the CAC-40 in Paris also higher by about a tenth of a percent. And on the DAX 30 in Frankfurt up about a third of a percent.

Another iconic company falling victim to the credit crunch we find out this morning Waterford Wedgewood, now this is a company announcing today that it's calling in administrators for bankruptcy protection. The Irish group best known for Wedgewood Pottery, Royal Dalton and Waterford Crystal collapsed after talks over possible investment in this business failed. It has officially called in the administrators.

Meantime European automakers say they are taking aim at Detroit they've said this before and failed. Will it work this time? Well, Volkswagen and BMW of Germany are gearing up to expand market share in the U.S. in the next few years. VW, investing in, in its first U.S. factory in two decades and expects to triple U.S. sales to one million vehicles by 2018; BMW meanwhile, introducing a new small car and expanding its distribution network. We'll see how this works out.

Now, let's go to Connell McShane for the three market movers of the morning. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Hey, good morning, Ashley and thanks a lot.

We are keeping an eye on these U.S. automakers today; certainly the big three from Detroit releasing their sales figures for December and the rest of 2008 later on today. And the numbers are expected to be pretty dismal with American carmakers selling 3 million fewer vehicles in '08; if that's the case it would be the biggest drop since 1974.

When it comes to our foreign competitors, Volkswagen and BMW are actually speeding towards an expansion in their stateside market according to a report in "Wall Street Journal" this morning. So that's an interesting kind of twist in things.

And this week also kicks off two pretty big tech shows. Apple is set to unveil some new products today and tomorrow when Mac World kicks off in San Francisco. Investors will be looking into new gadgets as well as any kind of insight at all into the health of the CEO, Steve Jobs, who has just become an issue of late. Jobs not expected to attend the MAC World this year.

And on Wednesday night it should be pointed out the Consumer Electronic Show begins out of Las Vegas. I'll be there to cover the latest new products later on in the week from CES.

Now, Pfizer is another one we're watching today, it's weighing a merger deal with a rival drug company or it would weigh one. The Financial Times reporting the CEO Jeff Kindler says the world's largest pharmaceutical company is quote, "open to opportunities and constantly looking at those which are big, small and in between." Pfizer's stock price, well, we have it is up behind you there 18.27 a share at the close; it's down almost 20 percent over that one year time span.

And those are your three market movers of the morning. Alexis, back over to you Alexis.

GLICK: All right Connell, thank you so much.

Well, New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson will not be joining the Obama administration as Commerce Secretary. Richardson pulled out yesterday citing an ongoing federal investigation into a state contract awarded to one of his political donors.

With more on this story we're joined by Michael Coleman the Washington, D.C. Bureau Chief for the "Albuquerque Journal" which has been covering the investigation for some time and Joe Monahan a New Mexico political veteran, who now writes a blog about state politics.

Michael let me start with you. Your newspaper reported on the investigation back in August. Apparently it has been on the docket now for many months.

What type of relationship is it that Governor Bill Richardson has with this financial company known as CDR Financial?

MICHAEL COLEMAN, ALBUQUERQUE JOURNAL D.C. BUREAU CHIEF: Well, their owner David Rubin had contributed about $100,000 to a couple of Governor Richardson's political action committees. And right around the same time that these donations were made the New Mexico Finance Authority, which is a quasi governmental agency with board members appointed by Governor Richardson, awarded this company a couple of contracts to help with some really complicated financial transactions, bond sales, bond swaps, et cetera.

One of those contracts was a no bid contract. And another one of those contracts CDR had issued -- had submitted the RFP but they weren't the top bidder, they weren't the top scored bidder on that but they still got the job.

GLICK: So in other words, as I understand it, they were the second in line of the bidders for the contracts so their suggestion here is this a pay for play scandal. On the other hand, Governor Bill Richardson's team says, we did absolutely everything right. In fact, the contract that we did with CDR Financial worked out to have some really important profitability for the state of New Mexico.

Tell me about that.

COLEMAN: Right. Now, they are very adamant about the fact that CDR saved the state a significant amount of money. And these bond swaps, these complicated transactions that CDR specializes in was not part of the original request for proposal.

But apparently New Mexico Finance Authority gave them points for that nevertheless. And it turns out they did one of those swaps. The only bond swap in New Mexico history apparently. And Governor Richardson and his team do say that that saved the state a lot of money.

GLICK: Joe, walk me through the normal type situation here because as I understand it, that there is a process for bidding out contracts like this, but this one appears as though it was done sort of quietly.

Tell me why that adds even more speculation to the story.

JOE MONAHAN, NEW MEXICO POLITICAL BLOGGER (ON THE PHONE): Well, there's really no reason that we know why that the paperwork is not on file with the state for this contract. I know Michael's newspaper has reported on that. And that's one of the aspects of the investigation, just how this deal was transpired.

The governor has run into problems down here before with contracts and campaign contributions. He's had to return campaign contributions several times after the press has reported that the campaign contributor was given a state contract.

So this pay-to-play situation has haunted Richardson somewhat, but not to the scale that it has now because it obviously is a national story.

GLICK: You know, Michael the $64,000 question that everybody is waking up with this morning is they are wondering how it is if you have been investigating this in your newspaper now, dating back to August, how it is that the Obama administration didn't know that this could be an issue in terms of his ability to take over this cabinet seat.

I mean what's the back end story here?

COLEMAN: Yes, that is the $64,000 question today. I think as you said, we had reported this back in August. I talked to members of the Senate Commerce Committee in December and did a story. And they said they were aware of this.

You know, my hunch is that maybe they weren't aware of the extent to which the FBI was looking into this. I'm not sure exactly how the conversations went between Governor Richardson's and Obama's transition team. There was some indications yesterday and some reports that maybe Governor Richardson wasn't as forthcoming as they would have liked.

Richardson spokesperson denied that to us yesterday and said he was were very forthcoming. So maybe some of this will play out in the next 24 to 48 hours. We'll see.

GLICK: Joe, how does this play in New Mexico, I understand he has some of the greatest ratings -- favorability ratings as a governor there. And could, if this investigation is put behind him, could he actually wind up in another cabinet seat at one point?

MONAHAN: Well, I think this has really hurt Richardson with Obama. He's not going to be hurt much in New Mexico. He is a well liked governor. He was re-elected with a record amount of vote. But Richardson has taken a major hit nationally on this. The cabinet positions are going to be filled.

Also Ken Salazar is now the Department Interior Secretary designate; that is an important Hispanic appointment that Obama has made so it puts less heat on the administration when it comes to the ethnic aspect of this.

GLICK: All right, well, Michael and Joe, we'll leave it at that. Of course, we'll continue to follow this story. Thank you gentlemen, very much.

COLEMAN: Thank you.

GLICK: Well, the House Financial Services Committee begins an open session this afternoon. They're exploring Bernard Madoff's alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's Inspector General could get a cool reception after "Wall Street Journal" reported this morning that the SEC examined Madoff's investment company eight times in 16 years.

Here for a preview of the House session, we're joined by Scott Garrett, he's the Republican Representative of New Jersey who is a member of the House Financial Services Committee and Harvey Pitt, former SEC Chairman and Kalorama Partners CEO.

Gentlemen, good to see you.

Harvey, let me start with you. "Wall Street Journal" reporting as we just talked about the number of investigations over the past eight years; pretty staggering statistics. What does this say about their failure to do the job?

HARVEY PITT, FORMER SEC CHAIRMAN: Well, I think it reflects something we've all thought might have occurred here, and that is the potential for human failure.

There appears to have been a fair amount of warning to the SEC, and it appears that when people looked into these issues, they came away without concluding that anything wrong was going on.

I do think it's important to remember that this was a deliberate fraud, and that Madoff was keeping a couple of sets of books.

GLICK: So all right let me come back to that in just a second, Harvey.

Congressman Garrett, let me go to you, because I understand one of your colleagues is running this, Congressman Kanjorski. And the real story here is he wants to figure out how did this situation occur in the first place? Was this a lack of proper oversight, and what kind of regulatory reform might it lead to?

Do you worry that it's going to lead to even more regulatory oversight than we already have?

REP. SCOTT GARRETT, (R) NEW JERSEY: Oh, we always have to worry about that whenever the government is involved, there's always -- what is the term -- a knee-jerk reaction to a crisis. A crisis as it were; obviously this is a problem whether you are a large investor or middle-sized investor, a private investor or small investor; a lot of people were significantly hurt in this situation.

Now, to his credit, the Congressman Kanjorski made the comment I think earlier this morning that there obviously is responsibility also on the part of the investor in this situation.

That each investor has to make, you know, their own due diligence, if you will, when they make their investments. So you have to look at both sides of the equation.

But back to your initial question, we have to be concerned whether government comes back with a knee-jerk reaction with saying we're going to give more authority, more power, more money into the very same agency that was responsible and failed on the job.

GLICK: So Congressman, as I understand it, the SEC's Chief, you know, chief risk officer, their inspector is going to appear today in front of Congress.

GARRETT: Yes.

GLICK: The number one whistle-blower though in this was originally scheduled to appear and is now not appearing. What do you hope to get out of it, and why the change in the lineup?

GARRETT: I can't give you an answer on the change in the lineup. Obviously there are questions that we would like to have put there, say, what did you know before and why hasn't the information come forth through all the investigations that the SEC has made?

The other aspect of this as well as far as the outcome of the equation, we'll have all these investigations. We'll get all the information we possibly can, but at the bottom line, where the government is not like the private sector. The private sector is such that if this occurred in the private sector, where business failed to do what they were responsible for doing, whether it's manufacturing something, or making something or turning a profit, that business at the end of the day would be out of business.

But when government is involved, the normal reaction to it is to do just the opposite. Throw more money, put more regulation on in place, and we saw that with the Enron situation and Sarbanes-Oxley. We came back with so much more regulation in place, that it actually was a detriment to business going forward --

GLICK: Right.

GARRETT: -- as opposed to a benefit to them.

GLICK: Harvey, let me go back to you because one of the things you touched on as you answered my first question is the fact of the matter is we now understand there have been offshore accounts. There may be many offshore accounts.

What would the SEC know or not know in that situation? I mean, you know, look, people are going to think this is egregious in how the SEC missed this but are you telling me that because there might have been offshore accounts, there could have been loopholes or opportunities for the SEC to miss it?

PITT: Well, the SEC has had a lot of experience in dealing with offshore accounts. Obviously there's bank secrecy and problems with getting all that information, but the critical function here was to go in and examine Madoff's operations, his books and records.

And I believe picking up on something the Congressman said, that it's physically impossible for any agency of government to do what we are expecting them to do. That doesn't excuse this particular situation.

But there are 11,000 registered investment advisors, and the SEC has 3,700 people on its staff. There's no way the SEC can continuously review these people. And so what's required is a whole new paradigm for dealing with inspection and examinations, and it has to be done quickly.

GLICK: You know, I don't know if you got a chance, Harvey, to see an article in the New York Times, the Sunday New York Times yesterday, an opinion article written about what needs to change at the SEC. But one of the key things that is talked about in this article is whether or not there's just too close a relationship between Wall Street and the role of the top risk officer, top inspectors at the SEC who exchange jobs between becoming a chief risk officer at the Wall Street firm and the SEC.

How do we make sure that we learn some valuable lessons here and that we don't allow something like this which involved this many investigations to go unnoticed?

PITT: Well, I think what you have to do is change the entire structure of examinations. That's what's the problem. You can't take some kids right out of college who are being paid $50,000 or $60,000 a year and ask them to examine $50 billion hedge funds.

What you need to do is have a completely different system, one that we proposed back in 2003 but which hasn't yet been adopted, and I think would solve a lot of this problem.

The SEC has to do a much better job of setting the standards and requiring independent examinations with reports both to the firm reviewed and the SEC, and then the SEC's personnel can go in and look at the issues that have been uncovered.

I think otherwise we're going to be just setting the SEC up for failure --

GLICK: Right.

PITT: -- on a continuing basis.

GLICK: All right gentlemen, we're going to leave it there. I know this is going to a hot topic, Congressman Garrett, Harvey Pitt, as always great pleasure seeing the two of you.

All right guys, coming up we're going to go live to the Gaza Strip with the latest on Israel's ground assault and escalating tensions in the Gaza area.

And this latest Mideast conflict has oil experts worried. We're going to tell you why in just a couple moments. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: Welcome back.

Well the fighting in Gaza continues. Israeli troops on the ground pushing deeper into the region. Dominic Waghorn of Sky News is live at the Gaza- Israeli border with the very latest. Dominic, good morning. Bring us to up-to-date on the very latest.

DOMIC WAGHORN, SKY NEWS: well, the fighting is continuing in Gaza. The ground force operation continues on three fronts. The Israelis have been fighting with Hamas in the south. They are targeting the smuggling tunnels there that Hamas have used to smuggle in weapons from Egypt. They have been hit with aerial bombardments and the Israeli forces are now on the ground fighting Hamas there. An armored column, a big armored column of somewhere between 100 and 150 tanks -- and armored personnel carriers has pushed right the way through the sea and is occupying land that effectively splits Gaza in two.

That means Gaza city which you will be able to see behind me if it wasn't for the haze is now encircled by Israeli forces. The fiercest fighting though, I think, has been in the area behind me. That's the north most bit of Gaza around the refugee camp of Jibalia (ph) and the town of Bethleher (ph). The reports are very close to fighting, house to house combat. According to one reports, hand-to-hand fighting in tunnels underneath those houses where an Israeli soldier was nearly abducted but was able to escape. There's no letup in the pace of this action.

GLICK: Dominic, talk to me about the humanitarian costs of all of this. I know the French president Nicolas Sarkozy is supposed to travel there today. What are the implications here?

WAGHORN: yeah, the Americans have stood full square behind the Israelis on this not critical of it but the British governments and the French have been critical of this ground invasion. And the main reason for that and the mounting concern is this humanitarian crisis and the mounting civilian death toll.

Around 500, over 500 people have been killed by this in Gaza. And we don't know how many of them are civilians, but we think at least a quarter of them, many of them women and children. There were reports today of three children being killed in a house, for instance, near that armored column with one tank shell. Another artillery shell wiped out a family of seven to the north of Gaza city.

The death toll yesterday was 40 and halfway through the day we're heading towards that number again today. The Israelis though say they have no alternative but to carry out this operation. What they are not saying is how much longer it will go on for.

GLICK: All right. Well, Dominic, we will leave it there. Thank you very much for bringing us up-to-date on the very latest. Of course be safe. Now let's send it over to Charles.

PAYNE: Thanks a lot, Alexis.

Well as the ten day assault escalates the price of oil continues to tick upwards; right now crude trading around $46. It had approached $47 earlier as some Islamic countries say that oil should be used as a weapon.
