Over the past 50 years, they built franchise after franchise throughout the world. Burger King's signature burger, the Whopper, sizzled onto its menu in 1957. McDonald's fired off its Big Mac in 1968. And the crispy, salty fries, well, they have been perfected over the years. Customers have flocked to these rivals, partly because of all the choices and the convenience, but they also haven't had to empty out their pockets to eat there.

The country's attachment to fast food didn't go unnoticed. By the 1990s, Kentucky Fried Chicken, Taco Bell and Subway were eating into these rivals' marketshare. And not much later, national obesity and nutrition concerns became prominent.

So these days, Burger King and McDonald's have expanded into healthy foods and even list the calories on their menus in some states and cities. Believe it or not, Burger King now offers veggie burgers and kids' meals. McDonald's now includes salads and chicken sandwiches.

Whether you have a beef with the burgers or you take a bite out of them, deciding to own a franchise might be found in the numbers. If you owned a Burger King franchise in 2004, your sales could have reached $1 million. And in 2007, sales could have risen to $1.2 million. A McDonald's franchise in 2004 could have earned you $1.6 million in sales, and three years later you could have brought in $1.9 million.

Would you buys a franchise today?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCSHANE: All right. So, for more on these burger wars, we're going to send it over to Alexis.

And to do so, I'm going to be back here, Alexis, in just a moment with some news out of Apple, because Steve Jobs has just sent a letter out, which he says, among other things, that he's been losing weight throughout 2008, but the reason has been a mystery to him and his doctors. We'll look through that and get some more details in just a moment.

GLICK: Yes. No, I'm just seeing this press release coming out from the board of directors.

Great point there, Connell. We'll cover that breaking news story in just a moment.

But let's finish up on the rivalry between McDonald's and Burger King. I think I'm a fairly good expert on this.

I'm joined by Sheri Daye Scott, editor-in-chief for "QSR" magazine, and Steve West, the vice president of equity research for restaurants for Stifel Nicolaus.

Good morning, guys.

Sherri, let me start with you.

Burger King and McDonald's, it's a rivalry that has been legendary. Where does it stand right now?

SHERRI DAYE SCOTT, "QSR" MAGAZINE: Well, you know, McDonald's is number one. They've been number one for a long, long time. But Burger King has kind of carved its own niche into the market, and they're doing well in that niche.

The two are playing in different markets. McDonald's is focusing on mom and kids, and Burger King is focusing on those young edgy guys. And both are number one in those markets.

GLICK: And so I imagine, Steve, that each of the two, Burger King and McDonald's, they've figured out how to remain competitors in a marketplace that they feel has enough room for each of them to be the dominant players.

STEVE WEST, STIFEL NICOLAUS: Yes, that's exactly right. They've both, over the last several years, have really evolved their menus to ad, as we mentioned before, healthier type options.

Now, is it healthy food? I wouldn't go that far. But when you can go to McDonald's and get grilled chicken sandwiches, salad, you can go to Burger King and get -- they call them apple fries, basically sliced apples, Mac and cheese for the kids, they are focusing on healthy items, they are focusing on premium items. That helps drive those sales at the franchisees that you mentioned earlier. So things are doing very well.

And when we think about the consumer here in the U.S., we typically spend almost half of our food dollars every year at restaurants. That trend hasn't changed that much over the last couple of years, even in these recessionary times that we're in.

What we're seeing is people are trading down to fast food because of the value, because of the convenience. It's definitely a win-win for McDonald's and Burger King right now.

GLICK: Yes, and it's been reflected in their stock price even while this recession, many suggest, began in the fourth quarter of last year.

Sherri, let me turn to you, because their marketing strategies are very, very different. I mean, Burger King has this virgin Whopper thing going on right now.

How is it that they are a reflection of the company and who they are and who they're trying to target?

SCOTT: Well, you know, to the point about what I mentioned earlier, the two different marketing groups, Burger King realized McDonald's is going to own those mom and kids, so about four or five years ago, they went after the younger, more edgier crowd. And Crispin Porter & Bogusky out in Miami is really leading that charge.

What they're doing is they're making people talk about Burger King. The Whopper, the virgin Whopper campaign, it's making people talk about their preferences.

Do you like the burger? Do you like the Whopper? Do you prefer the Big Mac?

Burger king has done a great job of just getting their name out into the public, getting people to talk about Burger King, whether it's subservient (ph) chicken campaign they did a few years ago where they had the dancing chicken, whether it's the king in those kind of edgy and somewhat creepy ads to people. People are talking about Burger King in a way they probably weren't five or six years ago.

GLICK: So, Steve, you know, in the midst of this serious economic downturn, each company is trying to do the right thing to differentiate themselves in the international environment, in addition to the domestic.

What are they trying to do to make sure that those marketshare numbers continue to grow as not just the U.S. economy faces recession, but the global economy faces a recession?

WEST: Well, they're doing really a lot of the same things. If you look at what McDonald's -- and I call it the McDonald's playbook, you know, when they came out with their plan to win in 2003, really focusing on the stores, making sure the stores looked nice, focusing on store level execution, and getting that menu right, making it "relevant," they're doing the same thing in Europe.

They're remodeling stores. They shut down a lot of older, dirty looking stores. They're making the menu relevant. You know, instead of just taking a cookie cutter U.S. menu and applying it to Europe, as they used to do, and the rest around the world, they're also making them -- they're customizing the burgers and the chicken and the things like that with local flare.

GLICK: Right.

WEST: And that makes it relevant. And they're also offering value. So they're really doing the same things around the world that they have been in the U.S., and it's been very successful, even in these downturns that we're seeing in Europe and Asia.

GLICK: All right, guys. Well, Sherri and Steve, we're going to leave it there. There's nothing more exciting than talking about the hamburger war at McDonald's and Burger King.

Thank you, guys. I'm starving now. I'm like ready to go get some fast food.

Thank you guys very much.

Well, we do have some breaking news surrounding the health of Apple CEO Steve Jobs. I want to go back to Connell. Connell has been following this story for us.

And Connell, I understand there is a statement coming out of the board of directors as well.

MCSHANE: Yes. Two things here.

One is a letter being sent out by Steve Jobs. We talked before you started that segment about the fact that he acknowledges the weight loss issues that we've all seen when Steve Jobs has appeared in public within the last year.

He says that he has been losing weight. And up until now, or up until recently, that weight loss had been a mystery to him. But now going over some of the reasons in this letter that he has written, says the doctors think they found the reason for it, and they expect it will take him until late spring to regain the weight and body mass.

Now, that reason, according to Steve Jobs and his doctors, is this -- he says that they cite a hormone imbalance that has been, to quote from his letter, "... robbing me of the proteins my body needs to be healthy." So, again, Steve Jobs saying his doctor says he has a hormone imbalance and that is the reason he's been losing weight. And they think that he can put this weight back on, and he will continue as apple's CEO during his recovery.

He says the remedy for nutritional problems is a simple one and it's straightforward. And they've already begun the treatment for it.

So on this news, it looks like the Apple stock is actually jumping up a little bit in premarket trading. We'll continue to follow that particular angle of it.

Now, you mentioned that the board of directors had put out a statement as well. They say, "It's widely recognized both inside and outside of Apple that Steve Jobs, one of the most talented and effective CEOs in the world..." And they go over what they said in the past.

They said if it ever comes to a day when Steve wants to retire, or for other reasons can't continue as the CEO, you will know it. That is basically the answer that they've given us in the past.

But again, Steve Jobs acknowledging the weight loss that he has had. As you see here in some of this video in which he face had looked drawn, a lot of people had talked about that the last time he had appeared on stage. And now saying it's because, Alexis, of a hormone imbalance and he is taking treatment for that.

GLICK: All right. Connell, thank you very much for bringing us up to date on that.

We of course are going to continue to discuss it right now, because we're going to switch gears here. Richard Suttmeier is with me, and Charles Payne is here with me to talk more about what the implications might be here for Apple.

You know, Charles, people have been saying for at least a year now that they've got to come up with a succession plan. Now, at least, we have some sense as to what the illness that's affecting the man behind Apple. But will there be greater calls perhaps to have him do what Bill Gates did at Microsoft, assume the chairman role and perhaps look for a future successor in the CEO role?

PAYNE: Well, I think the street would like to know who the successor might be, but I don't think anyone would like to see Steve Jobs step down if he's capable of doing both jobs right now. He is obviously the heart and soul of the company. That's why he's so important.

You don't talk about any other individual in the company there or associated with in this market more than Steve Jobs and Apple. So this is good news. The stock obviously indicating a little bit higher.

There's still going to be some rumblings, though. A lot of folks are saying, listen, you know, he suffered from pancreatic cancer. That is typically a pretty deadly disease. And until this is totally resolved, we see him put on weight, people are going to speculate.

GLICK: Richard?

RICHARD SUTTMEIER, VALUEENGINE.COM: Well, I'm going to take it from the standpoint of what Value Engine describes Apple computer. It seems like when it gets to an $85 handle, it becomes a buy-rated stock. When it gets into the $90s, it becomes a hold-rated stock.

So this morning, from a trading perspective, I'm going to see how many times this year I can make that same five to seven points. So my subscribers...

GLICK: So it's range bound though.

SUTTMEIER: It's range bound. And so I'm going to use this strength to, say, book profits on a buy-rated stock that's now a hold.

PAYNE: That's right, because our subscribers are in the stock, too, on an average of about 86 bucks. And I'm going to grapple with that as well because, technically, it doesn't have a lot of resistance between here and R100, but it comes down fairly quickly when it stops moving.

GLICK: How much, guys -- I don't want to say is the bloom off the rose? Because this is considered the darling in the tech world. But in terms of new innovation and new products? Or is that just because, as my husband said to me yesterday, we have Mac computers all over our house and you just don't need to upgrade them as often because the fact of the matter is, they're built terrific, they do the right things, and so you don't have to upgrade them very often?

PAYNE: Well, it's interesting you brought up Mac computers, because everyone has talked about the halo effect from iPhones and iPods, and how that would introduce audiences to the Mac computer. People are looking at this MacWorld Conference for something on the Mac PC. That's what they want to see, because they're doing exceptionally well in all other areas in the business.

We should also remind the audience, a pretty upbeat article in Barron's over the weekend on Apple. And this morning, (INAUDIBLE) Brothers also had positive comments on them. So the street and analysts liking what they're seeing.

GLICK: But Jobs isn't, as I -- right? He's not doing the presentation, or whatever, right?

PAYNE: He's not. He's not going to be...

(CROSSTALK)

GLICK: And that's the first time. So some are going to suspect that if he is not doing it, it's because either they're not excited about it or perhaps that's why they put this release out today, is because he's now being treated.

SUTTMEIER: Well, I would agree with that. He's being treated, and hopefully the man gets well again and comes back out in six months with the weight back on and announces another nano-nano, small-small device.

PAYNE: But by the same token, you do at some point want other people in the company to be associated with good news.

GLICK: Yes.

SUTTMEIER: Yes.

PAYNE: So hopefully whoever does make the presentation will say, "Hey, look at this." And everyone will say, "Wow!" so that we're excited about hearing from other folks. You know, any corporation, though, if the CEO is scheduled to speak and doesn't speak, the stock is going to get slaughtered.

GLICK: Yes. I mean, that's the thing that concerns me here, is that, you know, we've talked about this with the Warren Buffett situation as well, when you desire as a shareholder some kind of succession plan.

It doesn't mean it has to be put in place. I mean, look, Wal-Mart decided to do it at a time that some suggest, wow, why would you do it now? But at least something. And I guess maybe we can read into who they select to do the presentation.

SUTTMEIER: I mean, now it's "Wow, but I can't afford it" from the consumer standpoint. Let's see if I get my tax return. I get a tax refund, maybe a "wow" product, I'll spend it on that.

GLICK: Except that they made this great deal with Wal-Mart, right, where they're selling their devices. So that's -- you know, everybody seems to be moving in that direction.

PAYNE: Yes. Everyone was pretty excited about it. They seem to be doing -- firing on all cylinders right now outside of the health issue with Steve Jobs.

SUTTMEIER: Right.

GLICK: All right, guys. We're going to leave it there.

Richard and Charles, thank you, guys, very much.

Let's go to Ashley Webster in London and get a check and update on what is going on in the overseas markets. And he's also going to bring us up to date on what is happening with Woolworths.

WEBSTER: Yes. Thank you, Alexis. That's the big story.

Tomorrow, the 600 remaining Woolworth stores will close in the United Kingdom, bringing to a close an era of retail discounting. Really, they really were the original Wal-Marts, as one much my guests just referred to it. We'll get to that in a minute.

Now, the U.S. stores that, of course, become synonymous with American retail, the Woolworth stores in the United States even played a role in the civil rights movement. They began closing their doors though in the U.S. some 29 years ago, converting in many cases to a new store, the Foot Locker. We'll explain how that happened as well.

So for more on Woolworths' international legacy, I am joined by Sam Poser, who is vice president and senior researcher analyst for Sterne, Agee & Leach. And also joining me here in studio, Allyson Stewart-Allen, who is director of International Marketing Partners.

And Allyson, I'll begin with you.

This really is the end of an era, isn't it? But you would have thought that someone like Woolworths were better prepared to handle an economic downturn than many other stores.

ALLYSON STEWART-ALLEN, DIRECTOR, INTERNATIONAL MARKETING PARTNERS: Yes, you would have thought so. And the thing that's fairly emotional for a lot of British people about the closure of Woolworths here is the fact that it's a store format that was quite innovative in its time.

You know, the five and dime was something that in the U.K. was beforehand not known. You know, this time, with the Woolworths, you can go in, you can choose what you want, it's very discount-oriented and invented the discount category of retailing in the U.K. So oddly enough, the fact that it invented this category here, and now this innovator is no longer...

WEBSTER: So what went wrong? That's the question.

STEWART-ALLEN: Well, that's a really good point. What usually goes wrong with retailers of al kinds, and in particular Woolworths, is the fact that they didn't really keep up with who their customer was.

So they changed their categories, they didn't merchandise very well. They didn't have the depth of ranges that their customers expected.

The in-store experience became increasingly bleak as all of those around them upgraded their offerings. So they didn't keep up with the trends, they didn't keep up with the in-store environment. They didn't keep up with the merchandise. And all of that is a recipe for total disaster.

WEBSTER: Sam, let's go to you.

Woolworth closed its stores in the 1980s and '90s, closing the door on the final stores in 1997. So it's been some 11 years in the U.S.

How did this brand evolve into Foot Locker? How did that come about?

SAM POSER, VICE PRESIDENT, STERNE, AGEE & LEACH: Well, the last Woolworth store closed -- Woolworth divested to Europe in 1982, and the last Woolworth store closed in 1997. It was just the evolution of the business at the Woolworth Corporation, now Foot Locker Corporation, into an athletic specialty business.

And as that business became the dominant factor overall, Foot Locker spun off the various businesses that didn't work quite as well for them. And now it's evolved into the world's largest athletic specialty retail chain.

WEBSTER: Yes. And Sam, given the current economy, how is Foot Locker performing?

POSER: Well, Foot Locker's sales have been sort of stagnant over the last few years, but they've begun to manage their businesses significantly better than they have in the past. The stock to sales ratio, inventory levels and so on, have improved dramatically this year. Basically, the best ratio in about five years.

We expect earnings to -- we're not looking for much earnings growth in the next year or so, but we do see -- due to reduced top line. However, we do see the efficiencies improving dramatically and then beginning to take more share. They faced some problems recently because the athletic footwear trend has been soft, but that's improving now.

WEBSTER: All right. Well, Sam and Allyson, I just want to ask you, very quickly, five seconds, what kind of legacy does Woolworths leave behind?

STEWART-ALLEN: Interestingly, the granddaughter of Mr. Woolworth, Barbara Hutton, had a house built in Regents Park called Winfield House.

WEBSTER: Right.

STEWART-ALLEN: And that is now the home of the American ambassador. So you can close the high street stores, but they're still here in another form.

WEBSTER: The legacy lives on.

STEWART-ALLEN: It does.

WEBSTER: All right.

Sam Poser, thank you very much for joining us.

Allyson Stewart-Allen -- I want to call you Allyson Stewart-Allyson. I just like the word Allyson.

Thank you very much, anyway, for being here.

STEWART-ALLEN: Thank you.

WEBSTER: All right. When we come back, "The One Thing You Should Know." So don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Now it's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

We get started with Ashley Webster in London.

Ashley, what do you have for us?

WEBSTER: Well, let me tell you, Alexis. Today is somewhat of a sad and interesting day. And I'll tell you why.

It's the number one day for divorces to be filed. In fact, this is the busiest week of the year, and this is the busiest day of the busiest week. And you know why? Because the stress of the holidays is the final straw that broke the camel's back, and today is divorce day. So it's not very encouraging, but somewhat interesting.

GLICK: That is very sad. How do you know that, Ashley?

WEBSTER: Yes. I know. Sorry.

GLICK: That's not good.

WEBSTER: Sorry.

(LAUGHTER)

PAYNE: It's sad, but I'm impressed how fast it happens. You know what? "What did you buy? Oh, no!"

GLICK: Yes. "How much money did you spend? You're out!"

All right, Jenna, what is your one thing?

LEE: Well, the one thing is this Apple story. I think this is the biggest story of the day. We had the stimulus plan, you had the auto sales, but really how investors take in what is going on with Steve Jobs, I think that's going to be the most interesting story to watch today, for sure.

GLICK: Yes. And his letter to shareholders was very passionate, very forthright. We're going to do more of that letter coming up on "THE OPENING BELL," but we'll show you it. But it was pretty incredible.

PAYNE: It is. And, you know, he's just one of these incredible guys whose story everyone knows, and a Horatio Alger-type story.

But I think, also, this stimulus thing with President-elect Obama, the notion of making tax cuts such an important part of this, just may be a very brilliant move. Gold has gone down a lot, the dollar is beginning to rally. I think international markets like the news, and I think a lot of conservative investors in America like the news as well.

GLICK: Yes. It's going to change the ballgame.

PAYNE: Yes.

GLICK: I think it is.

PAYNE: You know, he's taken bits from all -- he's taken bits from FDR, Eisenhower and Reagan. And...

GLICK: I can't wait to see this report that you're writing.

PAYNE: Yes. It's coming out great. It's coming out great. A lot of work though. I always bite off more than I can chew.

GLICK: I'm so excited. We're going to dedicate a lot of time to that, because he's writing this really in-depth report about the first 100 days for each of those presidents.

PAYNE: Right. And those are the three guys, I think, three presidents that I think are going to be very important, their game plans and how successful they were.

GLICK: All right. I look forward to it.

All right, guys. Well, before we go, we want to welcome San Diego, Cox Communications in San Diego.

(APPLAUSE)

PAYNE: Whoa -- San Diego, too? So we've got Connecticut, San Diego and Vegas.

GLICK: We've got -- yes, right? We've got Vegas, we have San Diego, and we have Hartford, Connecticut.

Welcome, guys. We're so excited to have you guys.

All right. Stay with us. "THE OPENING BELL" is coming up next.

END

Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza Violence2009-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisGov. Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza ViolenceLanhamFULL TEXT

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," President-elect Obama's choice for Commerce Secretary, New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson, well, he's bowing out of the position. We're going to find out why and what it means for the Obama administration.

And President-elect Obama rolling out a new stimulus package; he plans to discuss it with lawmakers today. We're going to have all the details.

And the House Financial Services Committee begins an open session today exploring Bernie Madoff's alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme and how the SEC missed it. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And it may be too early for a hamburger, but we'll take a look at the rivalry between burger giants, Burger King and McDonald's.

Today is Monday, January 5th, 2009. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning. And welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." Happy New Year everyone, I'm Alexis Glick. Back in the seat and ready to go.

Well, we're going to get the latest on Governor Bill Richardson's stepping away from his job as Secretary of Commerce in just a moment.

And the Madoff hearings begin today. The House Financial Services Committee will probe how it is that the SEC missed the scheme. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And what will 2009 look like for trading? We get hopefully off to a good start; at least so far. We'll continue to see whether or not that will work through.

And why would anyone want to start a new football league in this economy? We're going to find out.

But first take a quick look at the U.S. futures this morning as right now we're down 16 points; 8,942. The S&P right now down 1.60. The NASDAQ down 2.75, but we had climbed above that 9,000 mark just late last week which we hadn't been to since early November, we'll see whether or not it shapes up to be a good year.

Well, let's get things started this morning with the three things you should know.

President-elect Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats meeting today are looking to put forth a plan for $300 billion in tax cuts to both individuals and businesses. This is an attempt to gain Republican support for his more than $700 billion economic stimulus package.

And French President, Nicolas Sarkozy lands in Israel today to meet with Israeli and Palestinian authority leaders. Now, the president is there in an attempt to push for a cease-fire in of course, the war-torn Gaza area.

On the ground this morning Israel struck at new Hamas targets in Gaza as it tries to rein in rocket attacks by the terrorist group.

And Microsoft's dominance on the Internet, well it may be waning. The software giant saw the share of its Internet browser Explorer drop from 74 down to 68 percent last month. Making the biggest inroads -- Mozilla Firefox which landed 21 percent of the market share.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now, for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, we go to Ashley Webster in London. Good morning Ashley and happy New Year.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS EDITOR: And happy New Year to you too Alexis, and welcome back. Good morning everybody.

Let's go to Ashley Webster in London and get a check and update on what is going on in the overseas markets. And he's also going to bring us up to date on what is happening with Woolworths.

WEBSTER: Yes. Thank you, Alexis. That's the big story.

Tomorrow, the 600 remaining Woolworth stores will close in the United Kingdom, bringing to a close an era of retail discounting. Really, they really were the original Wal-Marts, as one much my guests just referred to it. We'll get to that in a minute.

Now, the U.S. stores that, of course, become synonymous with American retail, the Woolworth stores in the United States even played a role in the civil rights movement. They began closing their doors though in the U.S. some 29 years ago, converting in many cases to a new store, the Foot Locker. We'll explain how that happened as well.

So for more on Woolworths' international legacy, I am joined by Sam Poser, who is vice president and senior researcher analyst for Sterne, Agee & Leach. And also joining me here in studio, Allyson Stewart-Allen, who is director of International Marketing Partners.

And Allyson, I'll begin with you.

This really is the end of an era, isn't it? But you would have thought that someone like Woolworths were better prepared to handle an economic downturn than many other stores.

ALLYSON STEWART-ALLEN, DIRECTOR, INTERNATIONAL MARKETING PARTNERS: Yes, you would have thought so. And the thing that's fairly emotional for a lot of British people about the closure of Woolworths here is the fact that it's a store format that was quite innovative in its time.

You know, the five and dime was something that in the U.K. was beforehand not known. You know, this time, with the Woolworths, you can go in, you can choose what you want, it's very discount-oriented and invented the discount category of retailing in the U.K. So oddly enough, the fact that it invented this category here, and now this innovator is no longer...

WEBSTER: So what went wrong? That's the question.

STEWART-ALLEN: Well, that's a really good point. What usually goes wrong with retailers of al kinds, and in particular Woolworths, is the fact that they didn't really keep up with who their customer was.

So they changed their categories, they didn't merchandise very well. They didn't have the depth of ranges that their customers expected.

The in-store experience became increasingly bleak as all of those around them upgraded their offerings. So they didn't keep up with the trends, they didn't keep up with the in-store environment. They didn't keep up with the merchandise. And all of that is a recipe for total disaster.

WEBSTER: Sam, let's go to you.

Woolworth closed its stores in the 1980s and '90s, closing the door on the final stores in 1997. So it's been some 11 years in the U.S.

How did this brand evolve into Foot Locker? How did that come about?

SAM POSER, VICE PRESIDENT, STERNE, AGEE & LEACH: Well, the last Woolworth store closed -- Woolworth divested to Europe in 1982, and the last Woolworth store closed in 1997. It was just the evolution of the business at the Woolworth Corporation, now Foot Locker Corporation, into an athletic specialty business.

And as that business became the dominant factor overall, Foot Locker spun off the various businesses that didn't work quite as well for them. And now it's evolved into the world's largest athletic specialty retail chain.

WEBSTER: Yes. And Sam, given the current economy, how is Foot Locker performing?

POSER: Well, Foot Locker's sales have been sort of stagnant over the last few years, but they've begun to manage their businesses significantly better than they have in the past. The stock to sales ratio, inventory levels and so on, have improved dramatically this year. Basically, the best ratio in about five years.

We expect earnings to -- we're not looking for much earnings growth in the next year or so, but we do see -- due to reduced top line. However, we do see the efficiencies improving dramatically and then beginning to take more share. They faced some problems recently because the athletic footwear trend has been soft, but that's improving now.

WEBSTER: All right. Well, Sam and Allyson, I just want to ask you, very quickly, five seconds, what kind of legacy does Woolworths leave behind?

STEWART-ALLEN: Interestingly, the granddaughter of Mr. Woolworth, Barbara Hutton, had a house built in Regents Park called Winfield House.

WEBSTER: Right.

STEWART-ALLEN: And that is now the home of the American ambassador. So you can close the high street stores, but they're still here in another form.

WEBSTER: The legacy lives on.

STEWART-ALLEN: It does.

WEBSTER: All right.

Sam Poser, thank you very much for joining us.

Allyson Stewart-Allen -- I want to call you Allyson Stewart-Allyson. I just like the word Allyson.

Thank you very much, anyway, for being here.

STEWART-ALLEN: Thank you.

WEBSTER: All right. When we come back, "The One Thing You Should Know." So don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

GLICK: All right. Now it's time for "The One Thing You Should Know."

We get started with Ashley Webster in London.

Ashley, what do you have for us?

WEBSTER: Well, let me tell you, Alexis. Today is somewhat of a sad and interesting day. And I'll tell you why.

It's the number one day for divorces to be filed. In fact, this is the busiest week of the year, and this is the busiest day of the busiest week. And you know why? Because the stress of the holidays is the final straw that broke the camel's back, and today is divorce day. So it's not very encouraging, but somewhat interesting.

GLICK: That is very sad. How do you know that, Ashley?

WEBSTER: Yes. I know. Sorry.

GLICK: That's not good.

WEBSTER: Sorry.

(LAUGHTER)

PAYNE: It's sad, but I'm impressed how fast it happens. You know what? "What did you buy? Oh, no!"

GLICK: Yes. "How much money did you spend? You're out!"

All right, Jenna, what is your one thing?

LEE: Well, the one thing is this Apple story. I think this is the biggest story of the day. We had the stimulus plan, you had the auto sales, but really how investors take in what is going on with Steve Jobs, I think that's going to be the most interesting story to watch today, for sure.

GLICK: Yes. And his letter to shareholders was very passionate, very forthright. We're going to do more of that letter coming up on "THE OPENING BELL," but we'll show you it. But it was pretty incredible.

PAYNE: It is. And, you know, he's just one of these incredible guys whose story everyone knows, and a Horatio Alger-type story.

But I think, also, this stimulus thing with President-elect Obama, the notion of making tax cuts such an important part of this, just may be a very brilliant move. Gold has gone down a lot, the dollar is beginning to rally. I think international markets like the news, and I think a lot of conservative investors in America like the news as well.

GLICK: Yes. It's going to change the ballgame.

PAYNE: Yes.

GLICK: I think it is.

PAYNE: You know, he's taken bits from all -- he's taken bits from FDR, Eisenhower and Reagan. And...

GLICK: I can't wait to see this report that you're writing.

PAYNE: Yes. It's coming out great. It's coming out great. A lot of work though. I always bite off more than I can chew.

GLICK: I'm so excited. We're going to dedicate a lot of time to that, because he's writing this really in-depth report about the first 100 days for each of those presidents.

PAYNE: Right. And those are the three guys, I think, three presidents that I think are going to be very important, their game plans and how successful they were.

GLICK: All right. I look forward to it.

All right, guys. Well, before we go, we want to welcome San Diego, Cox Communications in San Diego.

(APPLAUSE)

PAYNE: Whoa -- San Diego, too? So we've got Connecticut, San Diego and Vegas.

GLICK: We've got -- yes, right? We've got Vegas, we have San Diego, and we have Hartford, Connecticut.

Welcome, guys. We're so excited to have you guys.

All right. Stay with us. "THE OPENING BELL" is coming up next.

END

Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza Violence2009-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisGov. Richardson bows out; Madoff Madness Hits the Hill; Mr. Obama's Money Plan; Reinvesting in Recovery; Will Burris Stay Seated; Gaza Violence

ALEXIS GLICK, FBN ANCHOR: Coming up this morning on "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST," President-elect Obama's choice for Commerce Secretary, New MexicoGovernor Bill Richardson, well, he's bowing out of the position. We're going to find out why and what it means for the Obama administration.

And President-elect Obama rolling out a new stimulus package; he plans to discuss it with lawmakers today. We're going to have all the details.

And the House Financial Services Committee begins an open session today exploring Bernie Madoff's alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme and how the SEC missed it. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And it may be too early for a hamburger, but we'll take a look at the rivalry between burger giants, Burger King and McDonald's.

Today is Monday, January 5th, 2009. "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST" starts right now.

Good morning. And welcome to "MONEY FOR BREAKFAST." Happy New Year everyone, I'm Alexis Glick. Back in the seat and ready to go.

Well, we're going to get the latest on Governor Bill Richardson's stepping away from his job as Secretary of Commerce in just a moment.

And the Madoff hearings begin today. The House Financial Services Committee will probe how it is that the SEC missed the scheme. We're going to go live to Washington, D.C.

And what will 2009 look like for trading? We get hopefully off to a good start; at least so far. We'll continue to see whether or not that will work through.

And why would anyone want to start a new football league in this economy? We're going to find out.

But first take a quick look at the U.S. futures this morning as right now we're down 16 points; 8,942. The S&P right now down 1.60. The NASDAQ down 2.75, but we had climbed above that 9,000 mark just late last week which we hadn't been to since early November, we'll see whether or not it shapes up to be a good year.

Well, let's get things started this morning with the three things you should know.

President-elect Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats meeting today are looking to put forth a plan for $300 billion in tax cuts to both individuals and businesses. This is an attempt to gain Republican support for his more than $700 billion economic stimulus package.

And French President, Nicolas Sarkozy lands in Israel today to meet with Israeli and Palestinian authority leaders. Now, the president is there in an attempt to push for a cease-fire in of course, the war-torn Gaza area.

On the ground this morning Israel struck at new Hamas targets in Gaza as it tries to rein in rocket attacks by the terrorist group.

And Microsoft's dominance on the Internet, well it may be waning. The software giant saw the share of its Internet browser Explorer drop from 74 down to 68 percent last month. Making the biggest inroads -- Mozilla Firefox which landed 21 percent of the market share.

All right, those are the three things you should know about this morning.

Now, for the three things you need to know about in the overseas markets, we go to Ashley Webster in London. Good morning Ashley and happy New Year.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FBN OVERSEAS MARKETS EDITOR: And happy New Year to you too Alexis, and welcome back. Good morning everybody.

We're off to a positive start and certainly in Asia overnight and so far in Europe we are also moving higher although not exactly setting the world on fire, but we are higher, and that's good.

London Exchange, the FTSE 100 up about a quarter of a percent, just a little more than eight percent. On the CAC-40 in Paris also higher by about a tenth of a percent. And on the DAX 30 in Frankfurt up about a third of a percent.

Another iconic company falling victim to the credit crunch we find out this morning Waterford Wedgewood, now this is a company announcing today that it's calling in administrators for bankruptcy protection. The Irish group best known for Wedgewood Pottery, Royal Dalton and Waterford Crystal collapsed after talks over possible investment in this business failed. It has officially called in the administrators.

Meantime European automakers say they are taking aim at Detroit they've said this before and failed. Will it work this time? Well, Volkswagen and BMW of Germany are gearing up to expand market share in the U.S. in the next few years. VW, investing in, in its first U.S. factory in two decades and expects to triple U.S. sales to one million vehicles by 2018; BMW meanwhile, introducing a new small car and expanding its distribution network. We'll see how this works out.

Now, let's go to Connell McShane for the three market movers of the morning. Good morning, Connell.

MCSHANE: Hey, good morning, Ashley and thanks a lot.

We are keeping an eye on these U.S. automakers today; certainly the big three from Detroit releasing their sales figures for December and the rest of 2008 later on today. And the numbers are expected to be pretty dismal with American carmakers selling 3 million fewer vehicles in '08; if that's the case it would be the biggest drop since 1974.

When it comes to our foreign competitors, Volkswagen and BMW are actually speeding towards an expansion in their stateside market according to a report in "Wall Street Journal" this morning. So that's an interesting kind of twist in things.

And this week also kicks off two pretty big tech shows. Apple is set to unveil some new products today and tomorrow when Mac World kicks off in San Francisco. Investors will be looking into new gadgets as well as any kind of insight at all into the health of the CEO, Steve Jobs, who has just become an issue of late. Jobs not expected to attend the MAC World this year.

And on Wednesday night it should be pointed out the Consumer Electronic Show begins out of Las Vegas. I'll be there to cover the latest new products later on in the week from CES.

Now, Pfizer is another one we're watching today, it's weighing a merger deal with a rival drug company or it would weigh one. The Financial Times reporting the CEO Jeff Kindler says the world's largest pharmaceutical company is quote, "open to opportunities and constantly looking at those which are big, small and in between." Pfizer's stock price, well, we have it is up behind you there 18.27 a share at the close; it's down almost 20 percent over that one year time span.

And those are your three market movers of the morning. Alexis, back over to you Alexis.

GLICK: All right Connell, thank you so much.

Well, New MexicoGovernor Bill Richardson will not be joining the Obama administration as Commerce Secretary. Richardson pulled out yesterday citing an ongoing federal investigation into a state contract awarded to one of his political donors.

With more on this story we're joined by Michael Coleman the Washington, D.C. Bureau Chief for the "Albuquerque Journal" which has been covering the investigation for some time and Joe Monahan a New Mexico political veteran, who now writes a blog about state politics.

Michael let me start with you. Your newspaper reported on the investigation back in August. Apparently it has been on the docket now for many months.

What type of relationship is it that Governor Bill Richardson has with this financial company known as CDR Financial?

MICHAEL COLEMAN, ALBUQUERQUE JOURNAL D.C. BUREAU CHIEF: Well, their owner David Rubin had contributed about $100,000 to a couple of Governor Richardson's political action committees. And right around the same time that these donations were made the New Mexico Finance Authority, which is a quasi governmental agency with board members appointed by Governor Richardson, awarded this company a couple of contracts to help with some really complicated financial transactions, bond sales, bond swaps, et cetera.

One of those contracts was a no bid contract. And another one of those contracts CDR had issued -- had submitted the RFP but they weren't the top bidder, they weren't the top scored bidder on that but they still got the job.

GLICK: So in other words, as I understand it, they were the second in line of the bidders for the contracts so their suggestion here is this a pay for play scandal. On the other hand, Governor Bill Richardson's team says, we did absolutely everything right. In fact, the contract that we did with CDR Financial worked out to have some really important profitability for the state of New Mexico.

Tell me about that.

COLEMAN: Right. Now, they are very adamant about the fact that CDR saved the state a significant amount of money. And these bond swaps, these complicated transactions that CDR specializes in was not part of the original request for proposal.

But apparently New Mexico Finance Authority gave them points for that nevertheless. And it turns out they did one of those swaps. The only bond swap in New Mexico history apparently. And Governor Richardson and his team do say that that saved the state a lot of money.

GLICK: Joe, walk me through the normal type situation here because as I understand it, that there is a process for bidding out contracts like this, but this one appears as though it was done sort of quietly.

Tell me why that adds even more speculation to the story.

JOE MONAHAN, NEW MEXICO POLITICAL BLOGGER (ON THE PHONE): Well, there's really no reason that we know why that the paperwork is not on file with the state for this contract. I know Michael's newspaper has reported on that. And that's one of the aspects of the investigation, just how this deal was transpired.

The governor has run into problems down here before with contracts and campaign contributions. He's had to return campaign contributions several times after the press has reported that the campaign contributor was given a state contract.

So this pay-to-play situation has haunted Richardson somewhat, but not to the scale that it has now because it obviously is a national story.

GLICK: You know, Michael the $64,000 question that everybody is waking up with this morning is they are wondering how it is if you have been investigating this in your newspaper now, dating back to August, how it is that the Obama administration didn't know that this could be an issue in terms of his ability to take over this cabinet seat.

I mean what's the back end story here?

COLEMAN: Yes, that is the $64,000 question today. I think as you said, we had reported this back in August. I talked to members of the Senate Commerce Committee in December and did a story. And they said they were aware of this.

You know, my hunch is that maybe they weren't aware of the extent to which the FBI was looking into this. I'm not sure exactly how the conversations went between Governor Richardson's and Obama's transition team. There was some indications yesterday and some reports that maybe Governor Richardson wasn't as forthcoming as they would have liked.

Richardson spokesperson denied that to us yesterday and said he was were very forthcoming. So maybe some of this will play out in the next 24 to 48 hours. We'll see.

GLICK: Joe, how does this play in New Mexico, I understand he has some of the greatest ratings -- favorability ratings as a governor there. And could, if this investigation is put behind him, could he actually wind up in another cabinet seat at one point?

MONAHAN: Well, I think this has really hurt Richardson with Obama. He's not going to be hurt much in New Mexico. He is a well liked governor. He was re-elected with a record amount of vote. But Richardson has taken a major hit nationally on this. The cabinet positions are going to be filled.

Also Ken Salazar is now the Department Interior Secretary designate; that is an important Hispanic appointment that Obama has made so it puts less heat on the administration when it comes to the ethnic aspect of this.

GLICK: All right, well, Michael and Joe, we'll leave it at that. Of course, we'll continue to follow this story. Thank you gentlemen, very much.

COLEMAN: Thank you.

GLICK: Well, the House Financial Services Committee begins an open session this afternoon. They're exploring Bernard Madoff's alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's Inspector General could get a cool reception after "Wall Street Journal" reported this morning that the SEC examined Madoff's investment company eight times in 16 years.

Here for a preview of the House session, we're joined by Scott Garrett, he's the Republican Representative of New Jersey who is a member of the House Financial Services Committee and Harvey Pitt, former SEC Chairman and Kalorama Partners CEO.

Gentlemen, good to see you.

Harvey, let me start with you. "Wall Street Journal" reporting as we just talked about the number of investigations over the past eight years; pretty staggering statistics. What does this say about their failure to do the job?

HARVEY PITT, FORMER SEC CHAIRMAN: Well, I think it reflects something we've all thought might have occurred here, and that is the potential for human failure.

There appears to have been a fair amount of warning to the SEC, and it appears that when people looked into these issues, they came away without concluding that anything wrong was going on.

I do think it's important to remember that this was a deliberate fraud, and that Madoff was keeping a couple of sets of books.

GLICK: So all right let me come back to that in just a second, Harvey.

Congressman Garrett, let me go to you, because I understand one of your colleagues is running this, Congressman Kanjorski. And the real story here is he wants to figure out how did this situation occur in the first place? Was this a lack of proper oversight, and what kind of regulatory reform might it lead to?

Do you worry that it's going to lead to even more regulatory oversight than we already have?

REP. SCOTT GARRETT, (R) NEW JERSEY: Oh, we always have to worry about that whenever the government is involved, there's always -- what is the term -- a knee-jerk reaction to a crisis. A crisis as it were; obviously this is a problem whether you are a large investor or middle-sized investor, a private investor or small investor; a lot of people were significantly hurt in this situation.

Now, to his credit, the Congressman Kanjorski made the comment I think earlier this morning that there obviously is responsibility also on the part of the investor in this situation.

That each investor has to make, you know, their own due diligence, if you will, when they make their investments. So you have to look at both sides of the equation.

But back to your initial question, we have to be concerned whether government comes back with a knee-jerk reaction with saying we're going to give more authority, more power, more money into the very same agency that was responsible and failed on the job.

GLICK: So Congressman, as I understand it, the SEC's Chief, you know, chief risk officer, their inspector is going to appear today in front of Congress.

GARRETT: Yes.

GLICK: The number one whistle-blower though in this was originally scheduled to appear and is now not appearing. What do you hope to get out of it, and why the change in the lineup?

GARRETT: I can't give you an answer on the change in the lineup. Obviously there are questions that we would like to have put there, say, what did you know before and why hasn't the information come forth through all the investigations that the SEC has made?

The other aspect of this as well as far as the outcome of the equation, we'll have all these investigations. We'll get all the information we possibly can, but at the bottom line, where the government is not like the private sector. The private sector is such that if this occurred in the private sector, where business failed to do what they were responsible for doing, whether it's manufacturing something, or making something or turning a profit, that business at the end of the day would be out of business.

But when government is involved, the normal reaction to it is to do just the opposite. Throw more money, put more regulation on in place, and we saw that with the Enron situation and Sarbanes-Oxley. We came back with so much more regulation in place, that it actually was a detriment to business going forward --

GLICK: Right.

GARRETT: -- as opposed to a benefit to them.

GLICK: Harvey, let me go back to you because one of the things you touched on as you answered my first question is the fact of the matter is we now understand there have been offshore accounts. There may be many offshore accounts.

What would the SEC know or not know in that situation? I mean, you know, look, people are going to think this is egregious in how the SEC missed this but are you telling me that because there might have been offshore accounts, there could have been loopholes or opportunities for the SEC to miss it?

PITT: Well, the SEC has had a lot of experience in dealing with offshore accounts. Obviously there's bank secrecy and problems with getting all that information, but the critical function here was to go in and examine Madoff's operations, his books and records.

And I believe picking up on something the Congressman said, that it's physically impossible for any agency of government to do what we are expecting them to do. That doesn't excuse this particular situation.

But there are 11,000 registered investment advisors, and the SEC has 3,700 people on its staff. There's no way the SEC can continuously review these people. And so what's required is a whole new paradigm for dealing with inspection and examinations, and it has to be done quickly.

GLICK: You know, I don't know if you got a chance, Harvey, to see an article in the New York Times, the Sunday New York Times yesterday, an opinion article written about what needs to change at the SEC. But one of the key things that is talked about in this article is whether or not there's just too close a relationship between Wall Street and the role of the top risk officer, top inspectors at the SEC who exchange jobs between becoming a chief risk officer at the Wall Street firm and the SEC.

How do we make sure that we learn some valuable lessons here and that we don't allow something like this which involved this many investigations to go unnoticed?

PITT: Well, I think what you have to do is change the entire structure of examinations. That's what's the problem. You can't take some kids right out of college who are being paid $50,000 or $60,000 a year and ask them to examine $50 billion hedge funds.

What you need to do is have a completely different system, one that we proposed back in 2003 but which hasn't yet been adopted, and I think would solve a lot of this problem.

The SEC has to do a much better job of setting the standards and requiring independent examinations with reports both to the firm reviewed and the SEC, and then the SEC's personnel can go in and look at the issues that have been uncovered.

I think otherwise we're going to be just setting the SEC up for failure --

GLICK: Right.

PITT: -- on a continuing basis.

GLICK: All right gentlemen, we're going to leave it there. I know this is going to a hot topic, Congressman Garrett, Harvey Pitt, as always great pleasure seeing the two of you.

All right guys, coming up we're going to go live to the Gaza Strip with the latest on Israel's ground assault and escalating tensions in the Gaza area.

And this latest Mideast conflict has oil experts worried. We're going to tell you why in just a couple moments. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
