urn:contentItem:5SN9-VBV1-F021-6131-00000-00Greg Clark platitudes don't go down well2018-06-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2Greg Clark platitudes don't go down wellAlistair Osborne

Clearing up after Boris Johnson is a full-time job. His diplomatic feats have included comparing former French president François Hollande to a Second World War German general administering "punishment beatings"; penning a limerick accusing Turkey's leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan of sowing his wild oats "with the help of a goat"; and flattening a ten-year-old Japanese schoolboy in a game of rugby.

Such capers made Mr Johnson the obvious choice for foreign secretary. But, even with the world to offend, he cannot resist straying beyond his brief. His latest target? Britain's business community, aghast at the government's shambolic Brexit negotiations. "F*** business" was his pithy aside about warnings from Airbus and BMW of the threat to jobs and investment. A theme reprised by health secretary Jeremy Hunt, who declared it "completely inappropriate for business to be making these kinds of threats".

All that's a bit of context, then, for The Times' CEO Summit: a head-on collision in the making between our business and political leaders. Did it turn out that way? Well, not publicly - partly because both Theresa May and business secretary Greg Clark did their bit to repair relations. But privately? The pair's platitudes did not go down well. And not only over Brexit, but issues spanning business rates and the apprenticeship levy. Asked if he might ask the PM a tricky question, one FTSE-100 boss merely said: "What's the point?"

True, she struck the right sort of tone, ingeniously finding new ways to trot out the same banalities. Business "provides the backbone of the economy"; it was the "heart of how we are going to develop this country"; "it's right that we listen to the voice of business". Yes, better than Boris. But anything for Airbus? No more than: "We are preparing for all [Brexit] eventualities".

At one point, she seemed to be reading out random bits of November's 256-page industrial strategy doorstopper: a curtain raiser for its author. Mr Clark is pro-business enough - he'd be in the wrong job if he wasn't. He was applauded, too, by Paul Drechsler, vice president of the CBI, for saying Airbus was "entitled to be listened to with respect" - and also urged to impress upon his cabinet colleagues "the immense damage they are doing talking down business".

But Mr Clark also comes over like an economics student who, unsure what to put in his dissertation, just chucks in everything he knows and hopes it makes sense. What exactly is his strategy? And where's the clarity? Ducking a key question on post-Brexit caps for foreign workers was understandable: that's an issue for the cabinet. But the best he could offer after Pets At Home boss Peter Pritchard called for a "level playing field" with online rivals was a meander down the complexities of international tax rules.

As one underwhelmed company boss put it: "That's the first time I've heard Greg Clark. That's the sort of speech you give to a foreign audience." Duller than Boris's, too.

Fangs and claws Fangs for nothing. That was the general sentiment towards regulators and politicians over their handling of the big four tech platforms: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google, the so-called "Fangs". How come they pay so little tax and escape the regulatory burdens of established rivals?

Dame Carolyn McCall, the ITV boss, is hardly alone in finding it "quite odd" that Facebook can pay only £5.1 million UK corporation tax despite having £842 million in sales over here. Why, too, should the "publishers" Facebook and Google be allowed to self-regulate? "My biggest issue is how they are going to regulate online. No one knows how they are going to do that".

She called them "exponential" businesses. As Matthew Taylor, boss of the Royal Society for encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce, put it: "The data effect is reinforcing the network effect". He said Big Tech (the fifth "Faang" is Apple) had "unparalleled power in the history of capitalism" and suggested regulators break up Amazon.

How likely is that any time soon? Not remotely, according to the mood at the summit. One fear is that regulators and politicians don't understand Big Tech, not even culture secretary Matt Hancock, who says he does. Reining them in may take a consumer backlash, with users clawing back their data. The Facebook/Cambridge Analytica scandal shows why.

Outside chance So, what are the odds on that third Heathrow runway? 6-4 against. Or so says that famous bookie Willie Walsh, the boss of the airport's biggest customer, British Airways-owner IAG. Despite Monday's vote, he reckons there's more chance of it not being built: costs, air quality, noise, the pain of re-routing the M25. All could kill it.

Mr Walsh is particularly exercised about the "exorbitant" costs, starting at £14 billion before all the "excuses for massive cost escalation". And he has "zero confidence in Heathrow management's ability to deliver this project while keeping airport charges flat". That's what it claims it can do. Implausibly, too. For the passengers' sake, the Civil Aviation Authority must keep it to its word.

Cyber man Good advice to all chief execs from Ciaran Martin, boss of the National Cyber Security Centre. Who's of most interest to hackers? The systems administrator. "Ask them one question: are you using the same account to administer the network as you are using for your normal internet-facing work? If the answer to that question is 'yes' you have the reddest of red flags and you should go into emergency mode". Exciting.

urn:contentItem:5MKW-5T11-F15W-H086-00000-00GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS2017-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisGREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS

January 9, 2017

NEWS PROGRAM

GREGG LEMKAU, GLOBAL HEAD OF M&A, GOLDMAN SACHS,

MCCRACKEN: Thank you, Bonnie. Yeah, you're right, it's quite a list. Welcome, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Thank you.

MCCRACKEN: So, 2016 was a good year, not quite up to the standards of say 2015. We had obviously big global deals, buyer in Monsanto, A.T., Time Warner, et cetera. What do you looking at 2017? What is your crystal ball say?

LEMKAU: Well, I think the outlook for M&A in 2017 is quite strong. A lot of the factors that existed in 2015 and '16 that drive activity continue to persist. So you have low interest rates. You got abundantly available capital. You've got limited growth opportunities for corporate organically. And you have positive equity markets.

So that's all still in place. I think more importantly, some of the headwinds we saw in 2016, it's slowdown activity, are started this upside. And I think specifically, the regulatory environment. I think the expectation is we'll have a little bit of an easier regulatory ..

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie. I appreciate it. Sorry about that, Gregg.

LEMKAU: Sure.

MCCRACKEN: And I want to talk, so we wanted to give him an opportunity.

LEMKAU: Good idea.

MCCRACKEN: As you were saying, you expect easier regulatory environment in 2017.

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the expectation 2017 will be a bit of a loose for regulatory environment. And when you combine that with what we expect to be corporate tax reform, and in particular cash repatriation. It's actually a general sense of optimism in the business community, in particular, in corporate America that seems to be driving the desire to go out and be much more proactive on the strategic front.

MCCRACKEN: So how does repatriation? Is that something that's talk a lot about by, a lot by the M&A bankers in the M&A words? How do you think that might impact M&A? Because so many deals we've seen, you know, J&J right now talking to Kellyanne, a lot of these companies with offshore cast have used that to do deals in Europe, what happens if they bring that cash back to United States?

LEMKAU: So there something between $1 trillion to $2 trillion of cash trapped offshore by U.S. companies, and now the expectation will be able to bring that back in a relatively low tax rate and deployed in the U.S., so under deployed in a form of capital expenditures or in the form of M&A.

You've seen companies do lots of acquisitions outside the U.S. using that cash, but there a lot more targets in the U.S. and I think companies with the ability to deploy that capital in the U.S. whether it's a trillion or $2 trillion, and the cash that continue to generate back in the U.S., you'll see a big pick up in activity domestically.

MCCRACKEN: Yeah. And what are the industries that have the most offshore cash, is it tech for the most product?

LEMKAU: It's really the biggest the company. So it's mostly tech in big pharma but it's Google, Apple, Microsoft, Pfizer, J&J. You saw a lot of companies in the pharmaceutical industry, trying to do things to be able to access that cash offshore via M&A. If they can just bring that back and use it and deploy it via M&A in the U.S. they'll be able to do that much more easily.

MCCRACKEN: So they can bring it back, they'll use it for dividens. They'll use it for probably share the purchases, and then use for M&A is the anticipation if you will.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: OK. Will biotech and technology companies have a lot of cash as you were --

LEMKAU: Yes. It's really the big pharma companies with the big pharma companies as they look to grow, they probably going to deploy against biotech where the real fuel and the ability to drag the top line.

MCCRACKEN: Do you expect other certain trends that emerge in a given year? You know, when -- in 2016, you look back in a couple of years, you say that was the year of X or in 2008-2009, that was a certain, you know, era. What would you expect the trends might be in 2017?

LEMKAU: Yes. I think the big wave in 2017 partly fueled some of these cash repatriations, is going to be a significant amount of transaction across technology, media and telecom. You've seen the conversion happen in that sector, it was pretty remarkable. You've seen big transaction where Comcast bought NBC, Time Warner and AT&T trying to come together, even Verizon and Yahoo to an extent.

But the big distribution companies, looking to buy content, and the desire for this big media companies and big technology companies to get access to content and to get closer, to get some risk critical. And if you look -- you look at the Golden Globe last night, you had 17 nominations for shows or movies that was produced by Netflix or Amazon. I mean, imagine uttering that sentence five years ago.

And so, these companies acknowledging media and telecom, all of these are in content, all of these are in to get closer to consumer. I think needing to do that a lot via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: What's interesting is Amazon and Google, and even Apple have lots of cash. You know, everyday they're building our money, but they haven't done a lot of big deals. Do you expect that changes at some point? That they acquire, you know, acquire the arrivals or acquire entertainment companies.

LEMKAU: You see, that's the great question. I think these companies, you know, the five biggest market cap companies in the world are all with these big tech companies. They all happen to have big cash balances, sitting offshore, able to be brought back. And they've been really under penetrated in M&A.

So the real question is, when they will go pursue that as their top line growth starts to slow, which started. It's a natural time to do it. As the industry starts to converge is a natural time to do it. And the real question that really comes down to this regulatory piece, will the regulators allows them to do that, not just from the anti- trust standpoint but over our regulation where there's the FCC or the E.C. or the DOJ, of the FTC, will allow these big companies to get bigger via M&A.

MCCRACKEN: Is it the Goldman expectation, your expectation that the Trump administration be more like the Bush administration when it comes to anti-trust?

LEMKAU: I think it will be. You know, it's interesting a lot will remain to be seen. I think the hope is that we'll be a little bit looser. I'd say the Obama administration in the past year in particular, that a lot more stringent around M&A. There were $500 billion of transactions last year that fell way, largely due to anti- trust or interpretation of tax law. But if you look at Pfizer now or Baker Hughes and Halliburton, stay up for people (ph).

A lot of big deals fell away and the Obama administration kind of heading into their last year, got a lot more aggressive. I think the views that eases up to a degree and whether it returns all the way to that -- was under the Bush administration, that will get to be seen.

MCCRACKEN: Did you see situations where companies considered doing a deal. But, you know what, that will probably get a block here in this administration, let's read for that in a year.

LEMKAU: I think people that a lot of more anxious really as we head into 2016, and you saw some of these deals fall away. The last thing a board or a CEO wants to do is announce a big strategic transaction and how they can held up by the regulators for a long period of time. And then, ultimately, not happen.

It paralyzes a company. It's not great for the board. It's not great for the target or the buyer. And if somebody's transaction, we're getting stop, people really back to it in the table. I think if they see a looser regulatory environment, that much, more likely get back to the table.

MCCRACKEN: So Trump is going to have, he is in that real situation where he's going to have the House and the Senate, you know, but his party if you will. So as there, we're going to see big tax moves not just on repatriation but overall a big tax cut that might impact corporate taxes. How do you think that impacts M&A overall? What's that going to do to a company that's looking to do a deal?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I'd say, corporate tax cuts should also be a fuel to M&A. I think you'll see companies that have none core assets. It will be a lot easier to sell them if there's a reduce tax rate, and then having to have tax so we could just selling an asset. You'll see probably more divestitures than spin offs. I think people have been trying to do thing via tax, been off recently.

The one caveat to all of that is you may see a bit of a pause for awhile until it becomes clear what the tax rate is going to be. So you're going to sell an asset and you don't know if it's going to earn after tax at 35 percent or 25 percent or 15 percent. You probably want to wait to see what that new tax laws going to be but there's meaningful value, apparition around the actual earnings power of what you're selling.

So you could actually see a bit of a log until there's clarity around the tax report, and then a significant pick up and activity.

MCCRACKEN: All right. We're going to ask more questions for you. We throw that first back to Vonnie.

(BREAK)

MCCRACKEN: Thanks again, Vonnie.

So as Vonnie said, oil and gas could be busy this year. It was pretty slow in 2015-2016, maybe because a barrel of oil went from 100 something a barrel to as low as like $25 a barrel, I'm sure that had a big impact. What's your view or what oil and gas is going to do in 2017?

LEMKAU: Well, I mean, look at where the big energy companies, the oil and gas companies in particular, spent their time in focus in the past two years. It was really fixing their balance sheets and fixing their cost structures for dramatically reduce oil price. I had to figure out how to survive.

Lots of that self help is behind him, and you've got recovering oil price and you've got this general sense of optimism in the market that is likely to have all of them a lot more proactive around strategic activities. So I think you'll see a meaningful pick up in activity in the oil and gas piece, especially relative to what we saw in 2015 and 2016.

MCCRACKEN: What kind of impact does it have for a company when, you know, your core commodity, if the price of that is dropping so dramatically, you know, as I said, went from 100 I think in 2014 to below 30 in 2016. I mean, that just can't help a company who is thinking of putting himself on a block or considering expending billions to buy somebody.

LEMKAU: Well, it's fascinating. I think the companies that are in survival mode, need to really fix that capital structure. And most of them were built with CapEx budgets that didn't support $50 or that was more like $100 oil, so had a dramatically reshape that. I think the biggest companies who were positioned for the sustained downturn, weren't like they go and fix something off in the bottom because they want to make sure it was going to survive. They might rather see it go through bankruptcy and pick up the pieces.

I think a lot of the companies have now gotten through that, but the bottom has been hit and we start to recover and I think the biggest companies will feel a lot better about consolidating. And I think the smaller companies will fell like they not getting to a point where they can realize the value of doing an M&A transaction.

MCCRACKEN: It makes sense. It makes sense.

I want to circle back on something we're talking about earlier, which is M&A trust environment.

LEMKAU: Yes.

MCCRACKEN: And how -- there's a lot of things that would make a banker or a lawyer feel optimistic. What are some of the things that could be a concern in the M&A trust world? Because obviously, Donald Trump has been really fixated on jobs and maybe that starts to play into and could dampen some M&A this year.

LEMKAU: Yeah, I think that's right. I think a lot in the world is going to wait and see because you have a sense for how the new administration might behave in a pro business way but not exactly how they going to behave on any specific transaction or on transactions probably define. Lots of this consolidating transactions over the past year, who have been focus within the cost, which largely means taking that jobs. I think that's not going to be a sound bite or not going to be a narrative, this going to be particularly appealing in this administration.

I think the company is going to focus on doing big M&A transactions in particular, and the U.S. should be focus on, you know, creating a U.S. champion, or creating a winner in the U.S., of a global industry. And then, they go about doing an M&A transaction to create and focusing on growth and not focusing on cost cutting.

MCCRACKEN: Are there particular industries where jobs are more likely to be part of the equation in a big deal like industrial companies or oil and gas even?

LEMKAU: Yeah. I think the big consolidating transactions that have largely work have been industrial consolidation. We've actually seen it in consumer consolidation, the ability for these companies to come together and take out cost. Whether it's in a form of jobs, of sales people or R&D, have actually quite effective in driving the bottom line.

Again, but not necessarily feeding into the sentiment of where the countries going right now, which is going to be by creating jobs, is how I think they need reposition themselves around trying to put companies together in accelerated top line as opposed to just take out cost.

MCCRACKEN: I got it. Thanks, Gregg, good to have you.

LEMKAU: Thanks, Jeff.

MCCRACKEN: Back to you, Vonnie.

END ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5TPV-R821-F03R-N3BH-00000-00Grey Owl Capital Management 3Q18 Commentary: Long Tencent2018-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisGrey Owl Capital Management 3Q18 Commentary: Long TencentJacob Wolinsky

Nov 12, 2018( ValueWalk: http://www.valuewalk.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Grey Owl Capital Management commentary[1] for the third quarter ended September 30, 2018. 'We cannot choose our external circumstances, but we can always choose how we respond to them.' - Epictetus 'Learn to be indifferent to what makes no difference.' - Marcus Aurelius   https://www.valuewalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Grey-Owl-Capital-Management.jpg Dear Client, October brought a significant increase in market volatility and a broad equity sell-off[2] to match the late-January through early-February move lower.

From the September 21 high of 2941 to the (so far) October 26 intra-day low of 2628, the S...00 fell a bit more than 10%. At this point, it is still hard to know what to make of the move. Equity valuations remain very high. This is true even when one accounts for a sustainable shift in profit margins, the asset-light mix of US companies, and market structure1 that all argue for higher-than-historical average market multiples. Valuation presents a bad setup (but, that is not new). On the other hand, like the move lower in January, signs of increasing risk aversion (e.g. significant widening of credit spreads and narrowing of market participation) that typically begin developing months before a full bear market takes root, did not precede the current move lower. A near-term rebound would not be a surprise and we have added some equity exposure near the recent lows. Yet, given valuations and recent opportunistic transactions, we still have large positions in cash and Treasuries that should mute a continuation in the sell-off. Get The Full Ray Dalio Series in PDF Get the entire 10-part series on Ray Dalio in PDF. Save it to your desktop, read it on your tablet, or email to your colleagues Q3 hedge fund letters, conference, scoops etc[3] In equity accounts, we were active this quarter. Corporate transactions allowed us to realize meaningful gains in two equity holdings: Express Scripts and Zoe's Kitchen. We also closed an index position at a loss, added to an existing holding, and purchased two new securities. In fixed income accounts, we have made zero changes this year. The core of the fixed income portfolio remains a barbell between long-duration US Treasury bonds (stability) and floating-rate bank loans (growth). A meaningful move in the price of gold (signaling a change in inflation) and/or credit spreads (signaling a change in growth and investor risk-aversion) would provoke a shift in fixed income portfolio structure. Despite the equity market volatility, both of these series have remained relatively stable this year. Below we detail each of the transactions from the quarter.Sale - Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES)Last quarter we wrote in detail about our June 8 initial purchase of Zoe's Kitchen. On August 14, just prior to the company's second quarter earnings announcement, we added to our position. Given our conviction in the idea, we wanted to have a larger position if the 'strategic initiatives' they were pursuing developed sooner rather than later. We increased the size of the position to 5% of account value. On August 17, Zoe's announced an acquisition by privately held Cava Group, Inc. for $12.75 per share. Despite the $12.75 deal price, we were able to realize an average sale price of $13.25; our best guess as to why the stock traded at such a premium to the deal price is short covering. With an average cost basis of $9.18, our total return was approximately 44% over an average holding period of a bit more than one and a half months.Sale - Express Scripts (ESRX)As fast as the Zoe's investment developed, Express Scripts was the exact opposite. We first purchased shares in ESRX in November of 2012. We added to the position several times over the years, most recently increasing the position by about 70% following the March 8, 2018 announcement that Cigna would acquire ESRX for $92 per share in cash and stock. (The $92 per share price reflected Cigna's stock price at the time.) Our final purchase was at just over $69 per share, only slightly higher than the $66 per share basis we had established over the previous six years. We discussed the history of our ESRX position and the merits of the Cigna deal in our first quarter 2018 letter. In the end, we sold the entire position on September 5 after the stock rallied following the news that the Justice Department was close to announcing approval for the merger. Our sale price was slightly above $90 per share and within 3% of the 'deal price' based on the then per share value for Cigna. Our ultimate return was just over 34%, a terrific return on our April investment and an 'ok' result for our overall position.Sale - iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF (IEMG)sold the remainder of our position in the emerging markets[4] ETF in July. Since January, emerging market equities have been in a downtrend. The downtrend began following a modest increase in credit spreads in early 2018 and a stable-to-down gold price - conditions that are hostile to emerging markets and commodities. When those signals combined with a decisive move below the 10 month moving average, we used the modest bounce in July to exit the position. Including the lot we sold in May with this lot, we lost 7% on the position.Buy - iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF (TLT)We used the sell-off in long US Treasury bonds to opportunistically add a position in our equity accounts. The ETF positions (including this one, the gold ETF, GLD, as well as IEMG and EFA2, which we owned earlier this year) complement our individual security selection and provide exposure to 'primary' asset classes3 with two goals in mind. First, they enable a more balanced portfolio of securities that historically work best in different economic and market environments. Second, when signals from credit spreads and gold place us in a specific 'quadrant' we tilt the portfolio to the prevailing conditions. The hope is that the tilting enhances returns and minimizes portfolio volatility. We have discussed this 'all weather' or 'permanent portfolio' approach in more detail in past letters, most recently in our fourth quarter 2017 letter.Buy - Jefferies Financial Group (JEF)The financial services sector has fared poorly this year. While the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates 75 basis point this year to between 2.00%-2.25%, the longer end of the yield curve has increased only modestly. This puts pressure on a commercial bank's net interest margin. Year-to-date through October 26, the financial service sector (Spider) ETF (XLF) was down over 8%. JEF is worse - down over 22% year-to-date through October 26. Yet, JEF is a holding company and the Jefferies investment bank makes up only half of the entity. Further, an investment bank with a heavy weight toward advisory services is not impacted by the yield curve in the same way as a commercial bank. While the current yield curve[5] puts commercial banks under some pressure, from an operating standpoint, Jefferies has thrived recently. Through a series of transactions that monetized several of their larger investments, JEF increased tangible book value from $20.48 at the end of 2017 to $24.41 at the end of June 2018. In August, we added to our long-term position in JEF at just under $24 per share. The management team believes very strongly their stock price is undervalued. They demonstrated this by buying back 26 million plus shares (over 7%) at an average price of $24.41 during the first nine months of the year. We have discussed this idea several times in the past in greater length, most recently in ourfirst quarter 2018 letter. JEF is now our largest individual equity position with a weight just over 10% of our typical account.Buy - Tencent Holdings Limited (TCEHY)Most readers are familiar with Facebook, Spotify, Netflix, Nintendo, and PayPal. Those are all separate, multi-billion dollar enterprises. In China, Tencent is a market leader providing all of those functions. Tencent's core network is WeChat and it has over 1 billion users. The network effect from connecting all of those users creates a significant moat. Today, Tencent earns the equivalent of about $35 dollars per user. For comparison, in the US, Netflix users pay $10.99 per month for a standard package. As China's wealth grows, we believe Tencent can increase its market penetration in communications, gaming, media, and financial transactions, which will boost the $35 dollars per user sales figure. The stock has been under pressure for a variety of reasons including the Chinese government's increased focus on regulating online gaming. Regulation in this area is a concern, but apprehension regarding regulation should be balanced with the understanding that the government benefits from the ability to collect data from a single network - there is a symbiotic (though not necessarily appropriate) relationship between the Chinese government and Chinese 'big-tech.' We purchased a small initial position in September at just under $42 per share. At that point, the stock was already down over 30% from its January high of $61 per share. We knew we were catching a falling knife so we kept the initial position small. Subsequent to the quarter end, we added to the position, lowering our basis to $38.50. ***** For sure, the Stoics (quoted at the beginning of this letter) model a useful way to live, but they are equally (perhaps even more) instructive regarding day-to-day decision-making. We have used recent individual security and overall market volatility to make opportunistic transactions in individual names. Zoe's developed about as fast as possible and Express Scripts took what seemed forever - our response, being patient when warranted, adjusting when facts changed, was all we could control. Despite the recent market volatility, nothing that has proven useful historically is signaling we should make any major portfolio modifications. This could change quickly - even in the next few weeks. Yet, despite the headlines and noise, we work hard to be 'indifferent to that which makes no difference.' Thus, our overall posture remains similar to our last few quarterly updates. We are wary of equity valuations yet do not see the historical signs of an immediate market breakdown. We continue to hold a neutral posture - neither aggressively bullish nor bearish. ***** As always, if you have any thoughts regarding the above ideas or your specific portfolio that you would like to discuss, please feel free to call us at 1-888-GREY-OWL. ***** Sincerely, Grey Owl Capital Management, LLC This article first appeared on ValueWalk Premium[6] The post Grey Owl Capital Management 3Q18 Commentary: Long Tencent[7] appeared first on ValueWalk[8]. urn:contentItem:60GG-FSC1-DXY4-X08D-00000-00Grilled by Lawmakers, Big Tech Turns Up the Gaslight2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 1THE SHIFTGrilled by Lawmakers, Big Tech Turns Up the GaslightBy Kevin Roose

It is less clear that tech executives' strategy of evasive answers will continue to work now that lawmakers have begun doing their homework.

When Mark Zuckerberg appeared in front of Congress two years ago, the Facebook chief executive's memorable retort to a clueless questioner was ''Senator, we run ads.'' After Wednesday's marathon appearance by Mr. Zuckerberg and three other tech titans at a House hearing on competition in the tech industry, a more fitting quote might be ''Congresswoman, I'm not sure what you would mean by 'threaten.'''

That was Mr. Zuckerberg's evasive answer to a question asked by Representative Pramila Jayapal, a Democrat from Washington, about whether Facebook had ever threatened to squash smaller competitors by copying their products if they wouldn't let Facebook acquire them.

It was a good question with a clear-cut answer. Facebook's copy-and-crush approach has been well documented for years, and Ms. Jayapal brought even more receipts -- previously undisclosed messages in which Mr. Zuckerberg issued thinly veiled threats to Kevin Systrom, the co-founder of Instagram, about what would happen to his company if he refused to sell.

An honest Mr. Zuckerberg might have replied, ''Yes, Congresswoman, like most successful tech companies, we acquire potential competitors all the time, and copy the ones we can't buy. That's how we've avoided going extinct like MySpace or Friendster, and we're about to do it again with Instagram Reels, our new TikTok clone.'' That would have been an illuminating answer, and one that could have let lawmakers in on the kill-or-be-killed ethos of Silicon Valley. Instead, he dodged and weaved, trying to explain away the emails without admitting the obvious.

He did the same thing when Representative Hank Johnson, Democrat of Georgia, pressed him for answers about Facebook Research -- an app that was used to snoop on users' smartphone usage and give Facebook detailed data about its competitors. Mr. Zuckerberg initially said he wasn't familiar with the app, even though Apple's decision to bar it from its App Store nearly caused a meltdown at his company last year. (He later said he misspoke, and that he remembered it.)

I don't mean to pick on Mr. Zuckerberg. Every other witness at Wednesday's hearing -- Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Sundar Pichai of Google and Tim Cook of Apple -- also dodged lawmakers' most pointed questions, or professed their ignorance.

The result was a hearing that, at times, felt less like a reckoning than an attempted gaslighting -- a group of savvy executives trying to convince lawmakers that the evidence that their yearslong antitrust investigation had dug up wasn't really evidence of anything.

The performance wasn't particularly convincing. You don't become a tech mogul by being sloppy or forgetful, and it strains credulity to imagine that these four hypercompetitive, detail-obsessed men -- all of whom had many weeks to prepare for Wednesday's hearing -- simply didn't remember major decisions they'd made.

At one point, Mr. Bezos was asked about a recent Wall Street Journal report that Amazon had set up a venture capital fund to invest in start-ups, only to then introduce its own versions of those start-ups' products.

''I don't know the specifics of that situation,'' Mr. Bezos replied.

At another point, Mr. Pichai, asked to explain whether it was anticompetitive for Google to threaten to delist Yelp if it didn't allow the company's search engine to use its listings in its featured snippets, said he was ''happy to engage and understand the specifics'' at a later date. Yelp has complained publicly about Google's search engine for years.

And confronted with emails acquired by House investigators in which Apple employees promised to fast-track a company through its App Store approval process -- a seeming contradiction of Mr. Cook's assertion that it treated all developers equally -- Mr. Cook responded, ''I don't know about that, sir.''

Give the executives this: It's hard to have nuanced conversations about complex and often technical topics in front of an audience of hostile politicians, some of whom seemed more interested in generating fiery clips for their Facebook pages than investigating antitrust concerns. And the panel's format -- rapid-fire rounds of questioning conducted over video conference, with each member given only five minutes at a time to question the witnesses -- nearly guaranteed that the conversation would remain surface-level.

In addition, many Republican members of the subcommittee seemed to have no interest in antitrust issues at all, preferring instead to ride partisan hobby horses like claims of anti-conservative bias on social media.

But many Democratic members came armed with real, substantive questions that deserved a fuller airing. The executives' choice to sidestep these questions -- or their inability to answer before being cut off -- may signal that they still believe they can run circles around Congress without engaging in hard, detailed conversations about how they exercise their power.

That may have been a reasonable conclusion to draw after the past several years, a period in which Silicon Valley giants added hundreds of billions of dollars in market value while Washington barely gave it a passing glance. Despite plenty of clamoring, lawmakers have failed to pass any meaningful privacy or data protection laws during President Trump's time in office, and Mr. Trump has shown little interest in any tech regulation that does not involve his own Twitter account.

But it is less clear that a say-nothing strategy will continue to work, now that lawmakers have begun doing their homework. Sure, some members of Congress may still need their iPhones explained to them, but there is real expertise on Capitol Hill that wasn't there even a year ago, and new allies who are willing to give Congress the ammunition it needs.

When Mr. Zuckerberg appeared before Congress in 2018, tech expertise in Washington was a rare commodity. Now, antitrust experts schooled in the intricacies of tech platforms are helping Congress investigate.

One such specialist, Lina Khan, whose analysis of Amazon's anti-competitive business practices made her a star of the ''hipster antitrust'' movement, appeared at Wednesday's hearing sitting behind Representative David Cicilline of Rhode Island, whom she now advises. Tech industry leaders, who once refrained from criticizing their fellow titans out of courtesy or cowardice, are now speaking up about issues like the 30 percent cut Apple takes from purchases made through its App Store. And if Mr. Trump loses his re-election bid in November, the calls from Democrats to break up or regulate big tech companies will only grow louder.

None of this necessarily means that Congress is on the verge of reining in Silicon Valley's excesses. There are still plenty of lawmakers who would rather focus on promoting dubious claims of partisan censorship on Facebook, or complaining about fund-raising emails getting stuck in constituents' spam filters. And tech companies' generally good reputations with Americans -- not to mention their deep lobbying pockets -- may protect them in the end.

But at certain moments on Wednesday, each of the four tech executives appeared to be taken off guard by the rigor and depth of the questions they faced. If they were expecting to teach Tech 101 to a group of clueless lawmakers, they instead found themselves in the principal's office, being confronted with evidence of the spitballs they'd thrown. And they must have realized, in those moments, that they were seeing the beginnings of accountability.

None of this necessarily means that Congress is on the verge of reining in Silicon Valley's excesses. There are still plenty of lawmakers who would rather focus on promoting dubious claims of partisan censorship on Facebook, or complaining about fund-raising emails getting stuck in constituents' spam filters. And tech companies' generally good reputations with Americans - not to mention their deep lobbying pockets - may protect them in the end.

But at certain moments on Wednesday, each of the four tech executives appeared to be taken off guard by the rigor and depth of the questions they faced. If they were expecting to teach Tech 101 to a group of clueless lawmakers, they instead found themselves in the principal's office, being confronted with evidence of the spitballs they'd thrown. And they must have realized, in those moments, that they were seeing the beginnings of accountability.

urn:contentItem:5TY6-35V1-DXVP-V483-00000-00Grilled on Hill, Google chief Pichai denies firm censors conservatives2018-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:01ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYGrilled on Hill, Google chief Pichai denies firm censors conservativesDan Boylan

The head of Google told Congress Tuesday that the firm has no political bias, pushing back against President Trump and top Republican lawmakers who say the world's largest online search engine stifles content from conservative news outlets and personalities.

"I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that our products continue to operate that way," Google CEO Sundar Pichai said on Tuesday in highly anticipated testimony before the House Judiciary Committee. "To do otherwise would go against our core principles and our business interests."

The hearing was called by House GOP leaders to shine the spotlight on Google's search algorithms, which Republican critics say suppress conservative viewpoints and give prominence to liberal media voices because Silicon Valley's work force leans left politically.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, California Republican and member of the judiciary panel, cited statistics that show Google is responsible for 90 percent of all internet searches, but warned that there was a "widening gap of distrust between tech companies and the American people."

"We need to be sure than any political bias within Google's workforce does not leak into its search product," the California Republican said.

Democrats came out in defense of the firm, with the committee's ranking member, Rep. Jerry Nadler, New York Democrat, dismissing the idea that Google and other tech companies display any anti-conservative bias as a "fantasy" driven by Republicans.

Momentum has been building in Congress for legislation to regulate Google and other leading social media platforms firms for a score of problems that have arisen in the wake of Kremlin efforts to spread propaganda online during the 2016 presidential elections.

For Google, the bias issue has lingered, as have wider bipartisan worries across Capitol Hill that stricter privacy protections are needed for data the big tech companies' collect from their billions of users.

Mr. McCarthy also raised major concerns over recent reports that the Silicon Valley-based firm is poised to re-enter China and work with the ruling Communist party to create a search engine tailored to the government's censoring guidelines.

Mr. Pichai pushed back against the allegations, insisting Google never forgets its "American roots."

"It's no coincidence that a company dedicated to the free flow of information was founded right here in the U.S.," he said. "As an American company, we cherish the values and freedoms that have allowed us to grow and serve so many users."

His appearance before the House panel comes after he angered senators by declining to testify before a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing in September focused on foreign efforts to manipulate social media platforms during U.S. elections.

While Facebook sent its CEO Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter sent its CEO Jack Dorsey, the committee noted Mr. Pichai's no-show by leaving an empty chair for Google alongside the other witnesses.
